page.title: 2013 United States Men's Curling Championship – Qualification

revision.comment: /* Teams */Per consensus in discussion at [[Talk:New York#Proposed action to resolve incorrect incoming links]], replaced: Schenectady]], [[New York]] → Schenectady]], [[New York (state)|New York]] using [[Project:AWB|AWB]]
revision.text:
{{2013USNCC}} {{Main|2013 United States Men's Curling Championship}} '''Qualification''' for the '''2013 [[United States Men's Curling Championship]]''' consisted of three different paths. Four teams qualified directly through the High Performance Program or the Order of Merit system. The number of the remaining entrants to the national championships was cut down to six teams through a challenge round held in early January.
==Qualification system== Teams qualified to participate in the men's national championship through the High Performance Program, through the [[World Curling Tour]] Order of Merit, or through a challenge round.
===Automatic qualification=== Two spots in the nationals were awarded to two teams on the [[United States Curling Association]]'s High Performance National Program, established as an invitation-based program for the development of the top curling teams in the United States.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.curlingrocks.net/sites/default/files/press_pdf/national_program_teams2.pdf|title=Eight teams invited to High Performance National Program|date=7 July 2011|publisher=[[United States Curling Association]]|accessdate=6 December 2012}}</ref> The teams qualified through the High Performance Program were those skipped by [[Pete Fenson]] and [[Heath McCormick]]. Two more spots were awarded to the top two men's teams on the World Curling Tour Order of Merit standings table following the conclusion of the [[Iron Trail Motors Shoot-Out]]. If one or both of the top teams were already qualified for the nationals through the High Performance Program, the spot or spots would have been awarded to the team with the next highest position on the Order of Merit.<ref name="rules">{{cite web|url=http://www.usacurl.org/curlingrocks//images//rules_102412.pdf|title=2012–2013 USCA Rules of Curling and Competition|publisher=[[United States Curling Association]]|accessdate=6 December 2012}}</ref> The teams qualified through the Order of Merit were those skipped by [[Tyler George]] and [[John Shuster]].
===Challenge Round=== The remaining six spots in the nationals will be awarded to the teams that earn qualification spots through the [[#Challenge Round 2|challenge round]]. The challenge round was held in a triple knockout format, and was an open registration event. The teams that entered the challenge round were seeded through a strength of field ranking and through a peer ranking. The strength of field ranking was based on players' participation and performance in national championships and world championships. The seedings influenced the draw of the triple knockout event.<ref name="rules"/>
==Challenge Round== The challenge round for the men's nationals was held from January 2 to 6 at the [[Hibbing Curling Club]] in [[Hibbing, Minnesota|Hibbing]], [[Minnesota]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.usacurl.org/curlingrocks//images//122812_playdowns.pdf|title=2012 – 2013 USCA Championships Schedule|date=28 December 2012|publisher=[[United States Curling Association]]|accessdate=29 December 2012|page=7}}</ref> The teams skipped by [[Craig Brown (curler)|Craig Brown]], [[Greg Persinger]], [[Ryan Lemke]], [[Brady Clark (curler)|Brady Clark]], [[Mike Farbelow]], and [[Todd Birr]] advanced from the challenge round to the nationals.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://pressbox.teamusa.org/Pages/CURLING--Final-six-Nationals-berths-up-for-grabs-next-week-in-Hibbing--Minn-.aspx|title=CURLING: Final six Nationals berths up for grabs next week in Hibbing, Minn.|last=Kolesar|first=Terry|date=28 December 2012|publisher=[[USOC]] Press Box|accessdate=29 December 2012}}</ref>
===Teams=== The teams are listed as follows:<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.usacurl.org/curlingrocks//images//122812_playdowns.pdf|title=2012 – 2013 USCA Championships Schedule|date=28 December 2012|publisher=[[United States Curling Association]]|accessdate=29 December 2012|pages=24–28}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://pressbox.teamusa.org/Pages/CURLING--Eight-teams-now-qualified-to-2013-USA-Curling-Nationals-Championships-presented-by-Brooms-Up-Curling-Supplies.aspx|title=CURLING: Eight teams now qualified to 2013 USA Curling Nationals Championships presented by Brooms Up Curling Supplies|last=Kolesar|first=Terry|publisher=[[USOC]] Press Box|date=18 December 2012|accessdate=29 December 2012}}</ref> {| class=wikitable |- ! {{Infobox football club | clubname = AS Eliwidj FC | image = | fullname = Association Sportive Eliwidj FC | nickname = | founded = | ground = [[Aguelhok Stadium]]
[[Aguelhok]], [[Mali]]| capacity = ?| chairman = ?| manager = ?| league = [[Malien Premiere Division]] | season = 2013–2014 | position = | }} '''Association Sportive Eliwidj FC''' is a [[Mali]]an [[football (soccer)|football]] club based in [[Aguelhok]]. They play in the [[Malien Premiere Division]] the top division in Malian football. ==League participations== *[[Malien Premiere Division]]: 2013– *[[Malien Second Division]]: ?-2013 ==Stadium== Currently the team plays at the [[Aguelhok Stadium]]. ==External links== *[https://int.soccerway.com/teams/mali/elwidj/25877/ Soccerway] *[http://www.footballdatabase.eu/palmares.php?club=17181] {{Malien Premiere Division}} [[Category:Football clubs in Mali]] {{Mali-footyclub-stub}}

{{BLP sources |date=December 2015}} {{Use dmy dates|date=July 2013}} {{Infobox football biography | name = Bruce Grobbelaar | image =Bruce_Grobbelaar.png | image_size = 200px | caption = Grobbelaar in 2008 | fullname = Bruce David Grobbelaar | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|df=yes|1957|10|6}} | birth_place = [[Durban]], South Africa | height = {{height|ft=6|in=1}} | position = [[Goalkeeper (association football)|Goalkeeper]] | years1 = 1973–1974 |clubs1 = [[Highlanders F.C.|Highlanders]] |caps1 = 2 |goals1 = 0 | years2 = 1975 |clubs2 = Chibuku Shumba |caps2 = 13 |goals2 = 0 | years3 = 1976 |clubs3 = [[Highlands Park FC|Highlands Park]] |caps3 = 0 |goals3 = 0 | years4 = 1977–1978 |clubs4 = [[Durban City F.C. (1959)|Durban City]] |caps4 = 23 |goals4 = 0 | years5 = 1979–1980 |clubs5 = [[Vancouver Whitecaps (NASL)|Vancouver Whitecaps]] |caps5 = 24 |goals5 = 0 | years6 = 1979–1980 |clubs6 = → [[Crewe Alexandra F.C.|Crewe Alexandra]] (loan) |caps6 = 24 |goals6 = 1 | years7 = 1981–1994 |clubs7 = [[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool]] |caps7 = 440 |goals7 = 0 | years8 = 1993 |clubs8 = → [[Stoke City F.C.|Stoke City]] (loan) |caps8 = 4 |goals8 = 0 | years9 = 1994–1996 |clubs9 = [[Southampton F.C.|Southampton]] |caps9 = 32 |goals9 = 0 | years10 = 1996–1997 |clubs10 = [[Plymouth Argyle F.C.|Plymouth Argyle]] |caps10 = 36 |goals10 = 0 | years11 = 1997 |clubs11 = [[Oxford United F.C.|Oxford United]] |caps11 = 0 |goals11 = 0 | years12 = 1997 |clubs12 = [[Sheffield Wednesday F.C.|Sheffield Wednesday]] |caps12 = 0 |goals12 = 0 | years13 = 1997–1998 |clubs13 = [[Oldham Athletic A.F.C.|Oldham Athletic]] |caps13 = 4 |goals13 = 0 | years14 = 1998 |clubs14 = [[Chesham United F.C.|Chesham United]] |caps14 = 4 |goals14 = 0 | years15 = 1998 |clubs15 = [[Bury F.C.|Bury]] |caps15 = 1 |goals15 = 0 | years16 = 1998 |clubs16 = [[Lincoln City F.C.|Lincoln City]] |caps16 = 2 |goals16 = 0 | years17 = 1999 |clubs17 = [[Northwich Victoria F.C.|Northwich Victoria]] |caps17 = 1 |goals17 = 0 | years18 = 2002 |clubs18 = [[Hellenic F.C.|Hellenic]] |caps18 = 1 |goals18 = 0 | years19 = 2007 |clubs19 = [[Glasshoughton Welfare A.F.C.|Glasshoughton Welfare]] |caps19 = 1 |goals19 = 0 | totalcaps = 574 | totalgoals = 1 | nationalyears1 = 1977 | nationalteam1 = [[Zimbabwe national football team|Rhodesia]] | nationalcaps1 = 1 | nationalgoals1 = 0 | nationalyears2 = 1980–1998 | nationalteam2 = [[Zimbabwe national football team|Zimbabwe]] | nationalcaps2 = 32 | nationalgoals2 = 0 | nationalyears3 = 2018 | nationalteam3 = [[Matabeleland football team|Matabeleland]] | nationalcaps3 = 1 | nationalgoals3 = 0 }}
'''Bruce David Grobbelaar''' (born 6 October 1957) is a former [[Zimbabwe national football team|Zimbabwe international]] [[association football|footballer]] who played as a [[Goalkeeper (association football)|goalkeeper]], most prominently for the English team [[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool]] between 1981 and 1994. He is remembered for his gymnastic-like athletic ability, unflappable confidence and eccentric and flamboyant style of play. He has been the goalkeeper coach for [[Ottawa Fury FC]] of the [[North American Soccer League]] since 2014.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thewesternstar.com/Sports/2014-07-30/article-3816622/Grobbelaar-nets-coaching-gig-with-Ottawa-Fury/1|title=Grobbelaar nets coaching gig with Ottawa Fury|date=30 July 2014 |work=[[The Western Star (Corner Brook)|The Western Star]]|accessdate=31 July 2014}}</ref> In March 2018 he was announced as goalkeeper coach for the [[Matabeleland football team]].<ref>[https://twitter.com/JustinWalley10/status/972063066291605504]</ref>
Born in South Africa, Grobbelaar grew up in neighbouring [[Rhodesia]] (today Zimbabwe), and served in the [[Rhodesian Army]] before he joined the [[Vancouver Whitecaps (1974–84)|Vancouver Whitecaps]] of the [[North American Soccer League (1968–84)|North American Soccer League]] in 1979. He gained Liverpool's attention during a loan spell at [[Crewe Alexandra F.C.|Crewe Alexandra]] during the 1979–80 season, and signed for the Merseyside club in 1981. Making 628 appearances for Liverpool over the next 13 years, including 440 in the League, he won the League championship with the club six times, as well as three [[FA Cup]]s, three [[Football League Cup|League Cups]] and the [[1983–84 European Cup|1983–84]] [[UEFA Champions League|European Cup]].
Grobbelaar left Liverpool for [[Southampton F.C.|Southampton]] in 1994, transferred to [[Plymouth Argyle F.C.|Plymouth Argyle]] two years later, and thereafter played for an assortment of English lower-league teams, never for more than a few games.
==Club career==
===Early years=== In his teenage years, Grobbelaar was a talented [[cricket]]er and was offered a [[baseball]] scholarship in the United States, but a career in football was his main ambition. His footballing career started with a [[Bulawayo]]-based team, [[Highlanders FC]], in [[Rhodesia]]'s second biggest city. In his late teens he was signed up by [[Durban City Football Club]] in South Africa, but left claiming to have been sidelined owing to his colour in this predominantly black team — the team had played in an all-white league until the previous year. Immediately after leaving Highlands Park, he was conscripted into National Service, spending eleven months on active service in the [[Rhodesia Regiment]] during the [[Rhodesian Bush War]].<ref name="BBC210918">{{cite web |title=Bruce Grobbelaar: Ex-Liverpool goalkeeper talks war horrors, Heysel and match-fixing |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/sport/football/45596056 |publisher=BBC Sport |accessdate=21 September 2018 |date=21 September 2018}}</ref>
In 1979 Grobbelaar was signed by the [[Vancouver Whitecaps (NASL)|Vancouver Whitecaps]] of the [[North American Soccer League (1968–1984)|NASL]] after he had attended their [[scout (sport)|scouting]] camp in South Africa.
===Vancouver Whitecaps=== At the Vancouver Whitecaps, Grobbelaar played under the management of former [[England national football team|England]] and [[Blackpool F.C.|Blackpool]] goalkeeper, [[Tony Waiters]], making his debut on 4 August 1979 against the [[Los Angeles Aztecs]] away. The Whitecaps lost 0–2, [[Johan Cruyff]] scoring one of the Aztecs' goals. Grobbelaar spent the rest of the season as second choice to former [[Wolverhampton Wanderers F.C.|Wolverhampton Wanderers]] keeper [[Phil Parkes (footballer born 1947)|Phil Parkes]].
During 1979, he visited England to see family friends, and a chance phone call from [[Ron Atkinson]], brought him an impromptu trial with [[West Bromwich Albion F.C.|West Bromwich Albion]]. Atkinson was keen to sign Grobbelaar but owing to difficulties over gaining a work permit, the deal fell through. In stepped [[Crewe Alexandra]], signing Grobbelaar on loan on 18 December 1979. In an early League appearance for the Railwaymen in Division 4, the unknown Grobbelaar was named on the Team Sheet in the [[York City]] Match Day Programme as "Bill Grobbelaar". During his time at Crewe, Grobbelaar played 24 [[The Football League|League]] games and scored his only professional goal, a penalty, in his last game. By good fortune, on the evening when he gave his greatest performance for [[Crewe Alexandra|Crewe]], he was spotted by Liverpool's head scout [[Tom Saunders]].
At the end of the loan period, Grobbelaar returned to Vancouver for the [[1980 North American Soccer League season|1980 NASL season]]. Although the Whitecaps had signed former Scotland international [[David Harvey (footballer)|David Harvey]] from [[Leeds United F.C.|Leeds United]], Grobbelaar emerged as first choice and became a cult figure for the Whitecaps faithful.
===Liverpool=== By the time Liverpool FC had completed their research on Grobbelaar, he had returned to Vancouver with his loan spell now over. Liverpool approached Tony Waiters with the idea of taking Grobbelaar to [[Anfield]], and Waiters, who had a working relationship with Liverpool in the 1970s, paved the way for the move. Grobbelaar signed for Liverpool for £250,000 on 17 March 1981 as their reserve goalkeeper, but in mid-1981, regular goalkeeper [[Ray Clemence]]'s surprise departure to [[Tottenham Hotspur]]{{Citation needed|date=December 2008}} gave Grobbelaar his opportunity.
Grobbelaar made his debut on 28 August 1981 but failed to prevent [[Wolverhampton Wanderers F.C.|Wolverhampton Wanderers]] winning the league fixture 1–0 at [[Molineux Stadium|Molineux]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.lfchistory.net/viewgame.asp?game_id=1219|title=Wolverhampton Wanderers 1–0 Liverpool|date=29 August 1981|work=LFC History|accessdate=13 August 2010|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100622103959/http://www.lfchistory.net/viewgame.asp?game_id=1219|archivedate=22 June 2010|df=dmy-all}}</ref> Also making their debuts were defender [[Mark Lawrenson]] and midfielder [[Craig Johnston]]. His first clean sheet came a fortnight later at [[Anfield]] on 5 September, [[Arsenal F.C.|Arsenal]] were the visitors who were beaten by a 2–0 scoreline.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.lfchistory.net/viewgame.asp?game_id=1221 |title=Liverpool 2–0 Arsenal |date=5 September 1981 |work=LFC History |accessdate=13 August 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070218145326/http://www.lfchistory.net/viewgame.asp?game_id=1221 |archivedate=18 February 2007 |df=dmy }}</ref>
Grobbelaar's early days as No.1 were strewn with errors and the Reds struggled to obtain any sort of consistency, Grobbelaar taking a lot of the blame. By the end of the calendar year Liverpool were mid table in the league and looked to be out of the running for [[Football League First Division|title]] honours, especially as they had just lost to [[Manchester City F.C.|Manchester City]] 3–1 at Anfield in the [[Boxing Day]] fixture – a defeat which put [[John Bond (footballer)|John Bond's]] team top of the league. The New Year brought a new momentum as [[Bob Paisley]] began to get the best out of his players; they began the year in [[South Wales]] visiting the [[Vetch Field]] to play [[Swansea City A.F.C.|Swansea City]] in the [[FA Cup]], Liverpool were in fine form and thumped their hosts 4–0. This set them on their way in the league and dropped just seven of the 50 available points overhauling the points gap that [[Ipswich Town F.C.|Ipswich Town]] had opened on them.
Grobbelaar added the championship medal to the [[Football League Cup|Milk Cup]] winners medal he had gained at [[Wembley Stadium (1923)|Wembley]] on 13 March; the Reds beat Spurs 3–1, who had Ray Clemence in goal.
During the period 1981–1994, Grobbelaar played 627 first team games for Liverpool, becoming known for his eccentric and flamboyant style. In 1984, the [[UEFA Champions League|European Cup]] final between Liverpool and [[A.S. Roma]] finished 1–1 after extra time, and went to a [[Penalty shootout (association football)|penalty shootout]]. As Roma's [[Bruno Conti]] prepared to take his kick, Grobbelaar walked towards the goal smiling confidently at the cameras lined-up behind, then proceeded to bite the back of the net, in imitation of eating spaghetti. Conti sent his spot kick over the bar. Grobbelaar then produced a similar performance before [[Francesco Graziani]] took his kick, wobbling his legs in mock terror. Graziani missed and Liverpool went on to win the shootout 4–2.
Grobbelaar was retained by three of Liverpool's greatest managers; [[Bob Paisley|Paisley]], [[Joe Fagan|Fagan]] and [[Kenny Dalglish|Dalglish]], over a period of 13 years. His strengths were his gymnastic-like agility, and an unflappable confidence. He was never afraid to be seen to berate his defenders if he thought they had given easy opportunities to the opposition, such as in his verbal assault on [[Jim Beglin]] in the first all [[Merseyside derby|Merseyside]] [[FA Cup]] final against [[Everton F.C.|Everton]] in 1986. Over the course of his Liverpool career he won more medals than any of his contemporaries.
In [[1984–85 in English football|1984–85]], Grobbelaar brought down a spectator who had invaded the pitch during a game, allowing the police to handcuff the offending spectator.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=dqwq-wt69Vs&feature=related |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140628040905/http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=dqwq-wt69Vs&feature=related |dead-url=yes |archive-date=28 June 2014 |title=Broadcast Yourself |publisher=YouTube |date= |accessdate=16 November 2009}}</ref>
Although there were occasional challenges to his position as Liverpool's number 1, Grobbelaar was a virtual ever-present from Clemence's departure to the start of the 1990s which coincided with the end of the club's dominance. He was an ever-present in his first five league campaigns at [[Anfield]], when Liverpool were champions four times and runners-up on the other occasion. However, in [[1988–89 in English football|1988–89]], injuries and illness restricted his first team opportunities and he played 21 times in the league, with [[Mike Hooper (footballer)|Mike Hooper]] taking his place on the other 17 occasions. However, he was fit to face Everton in the 3–2 FA Cup win on 20 May 1989, though six days later he conceded a last minute goal to [[Arsenal F.C.|Arsenal]] midfielder [[Michael Thomas (footballer born 1967)|Michael Thomas]] on the final day of the league season as the league title was [[Liverpool 0–2 Arsenal (26 May 1989)|wrenched from Liverpool's grasp]] and headed to [[Arsenal Stadium|Highbury]] instead. A month earlier, he played in the FA Cup semi-final win over [[Nottingham Forest F.C.|Nottingham Forest]] which was played at [[Old Trafford]] after [[Hillsborough disaster|the original match at]] [[Hillsborough Stadium|Hillsborough]] was cancelled due to the tragedy that led to 96 fans dying on terracing just behind Grobbelaar's goal. Grobbelaar attended many of the victims' funerals.
It was the signing of [[David James (footballer)|David James]] from [[Watford F.C.|Watford]] in mid-1992 that spelt the beginning of the end for Grobbelaar. Although James struggled to impress at first, Grobbelaar's insistence on playing for [[Zimbabwe national football team|Zimbabwe]] gave James chances; Grobbelaar only played six times for Liverpool during 1992–93 and spent a short period on loan at [[Football League Second Division|Second Division]] side [[Stoke City F.C.|Stoke City]] where he made four appearances. James's uncertainty allowed Grobbelaar to regain his place in the first team at the start of the 1993–94 season, in which his performance, like the team's, started well but fell away badly. In a notorious incident in a Merseyside derby that year, Grobbelaar even physically assaulted young team mate [[Steve McManaman]].<ref>{{cite web|author= |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/football/2357669/Fight-club-when-team-mates-fall-out.html |title=Fight club: when team-mates fall out |publisher=Telegraph |date=4 April 2005 |accessdate=16 November 2009 }}</ref> He was ever-present until he was injured in the final minute of a 2–0 defeat at [[Leeds United]] on 19 February 1994. It turned out to be his final appearance for the club.
In 14 years at the club, he had won six league title medals, three FA Cup winner's medal, three Football League Cup winner's medals and a European Cup winner's medal.
===Southampton=== Grobbelaar left Liverpool in mid-1994, transferring on a free to [[Southampton F.C.|Southampton]]. He made his debut on 20 August 1994 in the 1–1 league draw with [[Blackburn Rovers F.C.|Blackburn Rovers]] at [[The Dell (Southampton F.C.)|The Dell]]. He spent two seasons with the Saints competing with another goalkeeper with a reputation for eccentricity, [[Dave Beasant]].<ref name = "ITN521">{{Cite book| title=In That Number – A post-war chronicle of Southampton FC |last= Holley |first= Duncan |last2= Chalk |first2=Gary | publisher=Hagiology Publishing | year=2003 | isbn=0-9534474-3-X|page=521}}</ref> Despite the fuss caused by the match-fixing allegations (see below), manager [[Alan Ball (footballer)|Alan Ball]] maintained faith in him, and he kept his place in the team for most of the 1994–95 season.<ref name = "ITN241">{{Cite book| title=In That Number |last= |first= | publisher= | year= | isbn= |pages=236–241}}</ref>
Allegations that Grobbelar had been match-fixing first appeared in November 1994. Nevertheless, in his next game, at home to [[Arsenal F.C.|Arsenal]], he managed to keep a clean sheet despite the media frenzy that surrounded the game.<ref name = "ITN237">{{Cite book| title=In That Number |last= |first= | publisher=| year=| isbn=|page=237}}</ref> The ''[[Southern Daily Echo]]'' reported that Grobbelaar was "swept along on a tidal wave of emotion, to emerge triumphant from the toughest match of his life".<ref name = "ITN237"/>
In the 1995–96 season, Grobbelaar only managed two games for the Saints, before moving on to [[Plymouth Argyle F.C.|Plymouth Argyle]].<ref name = "ITN245">{{Cite book| title=In That Number |last= |first= | publisher=| year=| isbn=|page=245}}</ref>
===After Southampton=== Grobbelaar spent the 1996–97 season with Plymouth, after which he spent short spells at [[Oxford United F.C.|Oxford United]], [[Sheffield Wednesday F.C.|Sheffield Wednesday]], [[Oldham Athletic A.F.C.|Oldham Athletic]], [[Chesham United F.C.|Chesham United]], [[Bury F.C.|Bury]], [[Lincoln City F.C.|Lincoln City]] and [[Northwich Victoria F.C.|Northwich Victoria]] over the next 2 years before returning to his native country.
==International career== Grobbelaar was born in [[Durban]], South Africa to ethnic [[Afrikaner]] parents. When he was two months old he emigrated to Rhodesia (renamed Zimbabwe in 1980) with his mother and sister to join his father, who had got a job on the railways there.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=EcxCOafwajw|title=The Official Story of Bruce Grobbelaar|publisher=Youtube.com|date=3 May 2015}}</ref>
Grobbelaar grew up and learnt his football in Rhodesia. He made his international debut for [[Rhodesia national football team|Rhodesia]] as a 19-year-old in a friendly versus [[South Africa national football team|South Africa]] in 1977.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rsssf.com/miscellaneous/oldest-youngest.html#mlc |title=Oldest and youngest players and goal-scorers in international football |publisher=Rsssf.com |date= |accessdate=2015-09-26}}</ref> Grobbelaar played for Zimbabwe in both of their [[1982 FIFA World Cup qualification (CAF)|1982 World Cup]] qualifying matches versus [[Cameroon national football team|Cameroon]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.11v11.com/matches/zimbabwe-v-cameroon-16-november-1980-236236/|title=Zimbabwe v Cameroon, 16 November 1980|publisher=11v11.com|date= |accessdate=2016-10-26}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.11v11.com/matches/cameroon-v-zimbabwe-12-october-1980-236196/|title=Cameroon v Zimbabwe, 12 October 1980|publisher=11v11.com|date= |accessdate=2016-10-26}}</ref> He also appeared for his country in a qualifying match for the [[1986 FIFA World Cup qualification (CAF)|1986 World Cup]] versus [[Egypt national football team|Egypt]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.11v11.com/matches/egypt-v-zimbabwe-28-august-1984-238645/|title=Egypt v Zimbabwe, 28 August 1984|publisher=11v11.com|date= |accessdate=2016-10-26}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.angelfire.com/ak/EgyptianSports/versusZIMBABWE.html#ZimbabweH84 |title=Egypt Versus Zimbabwe |publisher=www.angelfire.com/ak/EgyptianSports |date= |accessdate=2015-09-27}}</ref>
In 1992, he returned to the national team after an absence of several years. With a team including Grobbelaar and [[Adam Ndlovu|Adam]] and [[Peter Ndlovu]], Zimbabwe came just a victory short of qualification for the [[1994 FIFA World Cup qualification (CAF)|1994 World Cup]] under the guidance of manager [[Reinhard Fabisch]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/football/2015/aug/19/peter-ndlovu-bruce-grobbelaar-zimbabwe |title=When Peter Ndlovu and Bruce Grobbelaar made Zimbabwe dare to dream |publisher=www.theguardian.com |date=19 August 2015|accessdate=26 October 2016 }}</ref> Grobbelaar earned 32 caps for Zimbabwe between 1980 and 1998.
In 2018, Grobbelaar played a one off game for [[Matabeleland football team|Matabeleland]] in the [[2018 ConIFA World Football Cup |ConiFA World Cup]]. In it he came off injured after around 30 minutes.{{cn|date=June 2018}}
==Match-fixing allegations== On 10 November 1994,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://3.bp.blogspot.com/_ThhguC97EdA/SbAG_nNSCbI/AAAAAAAAAiw/L8k2YZDdyH4/s1600-h/I-SAVED.jpg |title=I-SAVED.jpg (image) |publisher=3.bp.blogspot.com |date= |accessdate=2012-08-15}}</ref> Grobbelaar was accused by the British [[tabloid newspaper]] ''[[The Sun (United Kingdom)|The Sun]]'' of [[match fixing]] during his time at Liverpool to benefit a betting syndicate, after being caught on videotape discussing match-fixing. He was charged with [[conspiracy (criminal)|conspiracy]] to corrupt, along with the [[Wimbledon F.C.|Wimbledon]] goalkeeper [[Hans Segers]] and [[Aston Villa F.C.|Aston Villa]] striker [[John Fashanu]] (only recently signed from Wimbledon), and a Malaysian businessman, [[Heng Suan Lim]].
Despite these allegations, Grobbelaar and Segers were allowed to continue playing, while Fashanu retired from playing less than a year after being charged. Grobbelaar [[plea]]ded [[not guilty (plea)|not guilty]], claiming he was only gathering evidence with the intent of taking it to the police. After two successive [[trial]]s, in both of which the [[jury]] could not agree on a [[verdict]], he and his co-defendants were cleared in November 1997. Grobbelaar later sued ''The Sun'' for [[libel]] and was awarded £85,000. ''The Sun'' appealed, and the case was eventually taken to the [[Judicial functions of the House of Lords|House of Lords]] where it was found that, though the specific allegations had not been proved, there was adequate evidence of dishonesty. The Lords slashed his award to £1, the lowest libel damages possible under English law, and ordered him to pay ''The Sun'''s [[costs (English law)|legal costs]], estimated at £500,000. In his judgement, [[Lord Bingham of Cornhill]] observed:
<blockquote>"The [[tort]] of [[defamation]] protects those whose reputations have been unlawfully injured. It affords little or no protection to those who have, or deserve to have, no reputation deserving of legal protection. Until 9 November 1994 when the newspaper published its first articles about him, the appellant's public reputation was unblemished. But he had in fact acted in a way in which no decent or honest footballer would act and in a way which could, if not exposed and stamped on, undermine the integrity of a game which earns the loyalty and support of millions."<ref>{{cite web|author= |url=https://publications.parliament.uk/pa/ld200102/ldjudgmt/jd021024/grobb-1.htm |title=House of Lords - Grobbelaar (Appellant) v News Group Newspapers Ltd and Another (Respondents) |publisher=Publications.parliament.uk |date= |accessdate=2015-09-26}}</ref></blockquote>
Grobbelaar was unable to pay the costs and was declared [[bankrupt]]. He and Segers did not retire from playing until some time after being cleared of their involvement in the alleged match fixing.
==Retirement and coaching== Grobbelaar moved back to his home of origin South Africa where he coached a number of teams with various degrees of success. He managed [[Seven Stars (South African Soccer Club)|Seven Stars]] in 1999 and took the team from the relegation zone to finish fourth in the final league table. In 2001, he took over struggling [[Benoni Premier United|Hellenic]]. While at the club, he saved them from relegation, and played in their last match of the season, against Kaizer Chiefs, starting the game, and substituting himself after 20 minutes after cracking his ribs. He was the oldest player ever to have played in the South African league, at 44 years old, until his record was beaten in 2013 by fellow keeper Andre Arendse.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.kickoff.com/news/34162/andrew-arendse-the-oldest-player-to-feature-in-south-african-psl- |title=Andrew Arendse the oldest player to feature in South African PSL - News |publisher=Kick Off |date=2013-05-02 |accessdate=2015-09-26}}</ref> He also spent time coaching [[Supersport United]], [[Manning Rangers]] (2004) and [[Bush Bucks|Umtata Bush Bucks]] (2004), as well as in Zimbabwe, where he was twice briefly player-manager of [[Zimbabwe national football team|Zimbabwe's national team]] in 1997 and 1998.
Grobbelaar came back to the United Kingdom briefly to help coach a number of clubs. Grobbelaar has recently {{When|date=September 2010}} stated that he "hopes to one day return to Anfield as the manager of Liverpool FC."
Grobbelaar returned to England in 2006 to play in a replay of the 1986 FA cup final against [[Everton F.C.|Everton]] for the Marina Dalglish Appeal, a charity for Cancer research set up by former team-mate and manager Kenny Dalglish and his wife, Marina, a cancer survivor. Liverpool won the match 1–0.
Grobbelaar played in the [[Sky One|Sky One's]] ''The Match'' in 2004 and ''The Match 3'' in 2006, keeping a clean sheet in both games.
Grobbelaar, also known as "Brucie", is still a firm favourite amongst the Anfield faithful, and was voted as No.17 in a poll [[100 Players Who Shook The Kop]] conducted in mid-2006 by the official Liverpool Football Club website. Over 110,000 worldwide voted for their best 10 players in the Anfield club's history, with Grobbelaar finishing 2nd in the goalkeeping stakes.
In March 2007, [[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool's]] official website announced that Grobbelaar would come out of retirement for a one-off game and play for non-league [[Castleford]] side [[Glasshoughton Welfare F.C.|Glasshoughton Welfare]] to help them in their fight for survival. He played against [[Maltby Main F.C.|Maltby Main]] on 14 April 2007, helping Glasshoughton to a 2–1 win.<ref name = "DM">{{cite web|title=Non-League side want Liverpool legend Bruce Grobbelaar for Gloucestershire Cup assault |url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/football/article-1228670/Non-League-want-Liverpool-legend-Bruce-Grobbelaar-Gloucestershire-Cup-assault.html|publisher=[[Daily Mail]]|accessdate=9 September 2010|location=London|date=17 November 2009}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last=White|first=Jim |title=Grobbelaar saves day for struggling minnows|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/columnists/jimwhite/2310988/Grobbelaar-saves-day-for-struggling-minnows.html|publisher=Daily Telegraph|accessdate=9 September 2010|location=London|date=14 April 2007}}</ref>
On 16 April 2009 episode of ITV's ''[[Hell's Kitchen (UK)#Series 4|Hell's Kitchen]]'' Grobbelaar wore a black armband on his left arm in remembrance of the 20th Anniversary of the [[Hillsborough disaster]]. On 22 April, he left the show citing a need to be reunited with his wife.<ref>{{Cite news| date=22 April 2009| url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/entertainment/8013699.stm | title=Grobbelaar quits Hell's Kitchen | publisher=BBC | accessdate=23 April 2009}}</ref>
He was persuaded to play for [[Winterbourne United F.C.|Winterbourne United]] in their [[Gloucestershire FA]] Trophy game against Patchway Town on 5 December 2009 but in the end did not make an appearance. Winterbourne at that time were managed by [[Nick Tanner (footballer)|Nicky Tanner]], who was a team mate of Grobbelaar at [[Liverpool F.C.|Liverpool]].<ref name="DM"/><ref>{{cite web|title=Grobbelaar says yes to Winterbourne|url=http://www.thisisbristol.co.uk/sport/Grobbelaar-says-yes-Winterbourne/article-1525997-detail/article.html|publisher=Bristol Evening Post|accessdate=9 September 2010|date=18 November 2009|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20091121030147/http://www.thisisbristol.co.uk/sport/Grobbelaar-says-yes-Winterbourne/article-1525997-detail/article.html#|archive-date=21 November 2009|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}}</ref>
During the [[2010 FIFA World Cup|World Cup 2010 in South Africa]] he appeared on Norwegian TV-channel [[TV 2 (Norway)|TV 2]].
Grobbelaar currently resides in [[Corner Brook]], Newfoundland, Canada.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cbc.ca/player/News/Canada/NL/Audio/ID/2280972196/ |title=Bruce Grobbelaar - Hillsborough Tragedy - West Coast Morning - CBC Player |publisher=Cbc.ca |date=2012-09-19 |accessdate=2015-09-26}}</ref> Grobbelaar is active in the local soccer scene, playing keeper for Corner Brook Men's Soccer League team West Side Monarchs, and occasionally lending his expertise to the Corner Brook Minor Soccer Association as a coach.
In May 2018 he became goalkeeping coach for the [[Matabeleland football team]], and on June 1 it was announced that he would join the playing roster for their remaining group games.<ref>[https://www.newsday.co.zw/2018/06/grobbelaar-back-between-goalposts/ Grobbelaar back between goalposts] Newsday.co.zw</ref> It was subsequently announced by head coach Justin Walley that he would start in goal against [[Chagos Islands national football team|Chagos Islands]] on 7 June 2018.<ref>[https://twitter.com/JustinWalley10/status/1004322105184391168 Justin Walley on Twitter]</ref>

revision.comment: ? appeal play ?!?
revision.text:
{{unreferenced|date=January 2008}}
[[Image:Baseball pick-off attempt.jpg|thumb|right|250px|A [[first baseman]] (standing in white) '''covering''' first base during a [[pickoff]] attempt.]] In [[baseball]], part of the [[infielder]]s' and pitcher's jobs is to '''cover bases'''. That is, they stand next to a [[baseball field|base]] in anticipation of receiving the ball thrown from another fielder, so that they may make a play on an opposing [[baserunner]] who is approaching that base. On a [[force play]], the fielder covering the base stands with one foot on that base.
In general, the [[first baseman]] covers first base, the [[second baseman]] or [[shortstop]] covers second, the [[third baseman]] covers third, and the [[catcher]] covers [[home plate]]. However, on [[ground ball]]s hit to the first baseman away from first base, the [[pitcher]] will cover first base instead. On a ground ball to either the shortstop or the second baseman, the other of those will cover second base.
With a runner on first base, when a ground ball is hit to the third baseman, second base will be covered by the second baseman, because unlike the shortstop he does not have to turn his back to the third baseman in order to get to second base. Likewise, with a runner on first base, when a ground ball is hit to the first baseman, second base will be covered by the shortstop, who unlike the second baseman does not have to turn his back toward the first baseman in order to get to second base.
When a runner on first base attempts to [[stolen base|steal second base]], the shortstop and second baseman will have arranged in advance which one will cover second base to receive the ball from the catcher. Likewise, when the pitcher attempts to [[pick off]] a runner at second base, the shortstop and second baseman will have arranged in advance which one will cover second base.
With [[baserunner]]s on first and second bases, sometimes the shortstop will cover third base on a [[Bunt (baseball)|bunt]], a coverage plan known as the "rotation play" or "wheelplay." This occurs if the batter bunts the ball toward third base so that the third baseman cannot cover third base because he is moving forward to field the ball.
If the defense is employing an extreme [[shift (baseball)|shift]], with the shortstop playing on the first-base side of second base and with the third baseman playing near second base (because by reputation the batter is anticipated to hit the ball to the right side of the infield), in some cases the pitcher may need to cover third base.
When the pitcher throws a [[wild pitch]], or when the catcher permits a [[passed ball]], so that in either case the catcher has to retreat farther into [[foul territory]] away from home plate to retrieve the ball, if there is a runner on third base the pitcher will cover home plate.
Depending on the situation, however, various fielders can cover any base, and sometimes even an [[outfielder]] can cover a base.
In [[American English]], the expression "cover your bases" used outside of a baseball setting means to be thoroughly prepared for something.
{{Baseball}}
[[Category:Baseball terminology]]

revision.text:
{{Infobox video game |title = Daley Thompson's Decathlon |image = Daley Thompson's Decathlon Cover.jpg |caption = |developer = [[Ocean Software]] |publisher = Ocean Software |designer = |programmer = [[Paul Owens (games programmer)|Paul Owens]], Christian Urquhart <ref>http://www.worldofspectrum.org/infoseek.cgi?regexp=^Daley+Thompson%27s+Decathlon$&pub=^Ocean+Software+Ltd$</ref> |artist = David Thorpe |composer = [[Martin Galway]] |series = |engine = |released = 1984 |genre = [[Sports game|Sport]] |modes = [[Single-player]], [[multiplayer]] |platforms = [[Commodore 64]], [[Amstrad CPC]], [[Sinclair ZX Spectrum]] }}
'''''Daley Thompson's Decathlon''''' is a [[personal computer game|computer game]] developed and released under licence by [[Ocean Software]] in 1984.<ref name='SU32'>{{cite news | first=Chris | last=Bourne | coauthors= |authorlink= | title=Daley takes the gold | date=November 1984 | publisher=[[EMAP]] | url =http://www.sincuser.f9.co.uk/032/ssftwre.htm | work =[[Sinclair User]] | pages = | accessdate =6 January 2009 | language = |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20010223023123/http://www.sincuser.f9.co.uk/032/ssftwre.htm|archivedate=2001-02-23}}</ref> It was released in the wake of [[Daley Thompson|Daley Thompson's]] popularity following his gold medals in the [[decathlon]] at the [[1980 Summer Olympics|1980]] and [[1984 Summer Olympics|1984 Olympic Games]]. A sequel, ''Daley Thompson's Super-Test'', was released in 1985.
==Gameplay== The player takes part in the ten events of the modern decathlon:
*Day 1: [[100 metres]], [[long jump]], [[shot put]], [[high jump]], and [[400 metres]] *Day 2: [[110 metre hurdles|110 hurdles]], [[pole vault]], [[Discus throw|discus]], [[Javelin throw|javelin]], and [[1500 metres]]
The player starts the game with three lives; failure to reach the minimum standard in an event results in the loss of one life. Success in the 1500 meters event results in the game returning to Day 1 to repeat the events with more difficult qualification criteria.
Depending on the computer, running is simulated by hitting two keys (representing the left and right leg) alternately and as quickly as possible or by moving the joystick from side to side as quickly as possible. The game rapidly gained a reputation among players as a "joystick killer" because of the constant vigorous waggling of the joystick required during many of the events.
The Spectrum version was the first game to use [[Speedlock]], a fast loader on the computer.<ref name="crash">{{cite journal|url=http://www.crashonline.org.uk/44/david_aj.htm|last=Eddy|first=Richard|year=1987|publisher=Crash|issue=44|title=The One David|accessdate=9 January 2013}}</ref>
==Music== The soundtrack of the C64 version of the game was composed by [[Martin Galway]] and [[David Dunn (disambiguation)|David Dunn]]. The introduction music is based on the 1978 [[electronic music]] piece "[[Solid State Survivor|Rydeen]]" by [[Yellow Magic Orchestra]] (YMO).
==Reception== ''[[Sinclair User]]'' gave the game a score of 8/10.<ref>http://www.worldofspectrum.org/showmag.cgi?mag=SinclairUser/Issue032/Pages/SinclairUser03200026.jpg</ref> It went on to become the biggest selling Spectrum game of Q4 1984.<ref>http://www.worldofspectrum.org/showmag.cgi?mag=C+VG/Issue037/Pages/CVG03700104.jpg</ref> The game won the award for Best (Overall) Arcade Game in ''[[Crash (magazine)|Crash]]'' magazine's Readers Awards 1984<ref>http://www.crashonline.org.uk/12/awards.htm</ref><ref>{{cite magazine |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |title=Crash Readers Awards 1984 |url=https://archive.org/stream/crash-magazine-12/Crash_12_Jan_1985#page/n95/mode/2up |magazine=[[Crash (magazine)|Crash]] |issue=12 |page=96 |location=Ludlow, Shropshire |publisher=Newsfield Ltd. |date=Christmas 1984<!-- cover says 1984/85 --> |access-date=2016-08-11 }}</ref> and was the Best Arcade-Style Game of the Year at the [[Golden Joystick Awards]].<ref>http://www.worldofspectrum.org/showmag.cgi?mag=C+VG/Issue044/Pages/CVG04400122.jpg</ref>
The game was included on the 1985 compilation ''They Sold a Million'',<ref>http://www.worldofspectrum.org/infoseekid.cgi?id=0011371</ref> along with ''[[Beach-Head]]'', ''[[Sabre Wulf]]'', and ''[[Jet Set Willy]]''. In 2017, the game placed on [[Eurogamer]]'s "10 games that defined the ZX Spectrum" list.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Mason|first1=Graeme|title=10 games that defined the ZX Spectrum|url=http://www.eurogamer.net/articles/2017-04-09-10-games-that-defined-the-zx-spectrum|website=[[Eurogamer]]|publisher=Gamer Network|accessdate=10 April 2017|date=9 April 2017}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist|30em}}
==External links== *{{moby game|id=/daley-thompsons-decathlon|name=''Daley Thompson's Decathlon''}} *{{WoS game|id=0001217|name=Daley Thompson's Decathlon}}

revision.comment: /* External links */
revision.text:
'''Dead rubber''' is a term used in [[sport]]ing parlance to describe a [[game|match]] in a [[playoff format|series]] where the series result has already been decided by earlier matches. The dead rubber match therefore has no effect on the winner and loser of the series, other than the total number of matches won and lost.
The term is used in [[Davis Cup]] and [[Fed Cup]] [[tennis]], as well as in international [[cricket]], [[field hockey]], the [[FIFA World Cup]], [[UEFA Champions League]] and [[Rugby World Cup]].
For example, in a Davis Cup series, each pair of competing countries play five matches (''rubbers'') where the winner is decided on a best-of-five basis. Once one team has reached three victories, the remaining match or matches are said to be ''dead rubbers''. [[International Tennis Federation]]'s last revision of the competition policies on dead rubbers is from 2011.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.daviscup.com/en/news/articles/itf-revises-davis-cup-dead-rubber-policy.aspx|title=ITF revises Davis Cup dead rubber policy|date=March 2, 2011|publisher=Davis Cup|accessdate=April 9, 2017}}</ref>
Since the result of a dead rubber has no impact in determining the winner of a series, dead rubbers are typically played in a less intense atmosphere, often allowing the team that has lost the series to obtain a match win. Sometimes, second-string players who have not played many matches in top-level competition are given the opportunity to play a dead rubber in order to gain experience. This practice makes completing a clean sweep of a series less likely.
==See also== *[http://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/rubber_match Rubber match] – decisive match in a series
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== * [https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/olympics/badminton/9443922/Badminton-pairs-expelled-from-London-2012-Olympics-after-match-fixing-scandal.html Badminton at 2012 Olympics]
[[Category:Terminology used in multiple sports]] [[Category:Association football terminology]] [[Category:Basketball terminology]] [[Category:Cricket terminology]] [[Category:Rugby league terminology]] [[Category:Rugby union terminology]] [[Category:Tennis terminology]]
{{sport-stub}}

revision.comment: Reverted edits by [[Special:Contribs/41.69.37.187|41.69.37.187]] ([[User talk:41.69.37.187|talk]]) to last version by Ben5218
/* Plot */ - Typo fix
revision.text:
{{Infobox film | name = He Got Game | image = He got game poster.jpg | alt = | caption = Theatrical release poster | director = [[Spike Lee]] | producer = Jon Kilik
Spike Lee | writer = Spike Lee | starring = {{plainlist| * [[Denzel Washington]] * [[Ray Allen]] * [[Milla Jovovich]]}} | music = [[Howard Shore]] | cinematography = [[Malik Hassan Sayeed]] | editing = [[Barry Alexander Brown]] | studio = [[Touchstone Pictures]]
[[40 Acres and a Mule Filmworks]] | distributor = [[Walt Disney Studios Motion Pictures|Buena Vista Pictures]] | released = {{Film date|1998|05|01}} | runtime = 136 minutes | country = United States | language = English | budget = $25 million | gross = $22.4 million }} '''''He Got Game''''' is a 1998 American [[List of sports films|sports]] [[Drama (film and television)|drama film]] written, produced and directed by [[Spike Lee]] and starring [[Denzel Washington]]. This is the third of four film collaborations between Washington and Lee. Washington portrays Jake Shuttlesworth, father of the top-ranked [[basketball]] prospect in the country, Jesus Shuttlesworth, played by [[National Basketball Association|NBA]] star [[Ray Allen]]. Jake, in prison for killing his wife, is released on [[parole]] for a week by the state's governor to persuade his son to play for the governor's [[alma mater]] in exchange for a much reduced prison sentence. == Plot == Jesus Shuttlesworth (Ray Allen), the top high school basketball player in the United States, is being pursued by the top college basketball programs in the nation. His father, Jake, is a convicted felon serving time at [[Attica Correctional Facility]] for accidentally killing his wife, Martha, ([[Jesus (name)|Jesus]]' mother) six years earlier. Jake is temporarily released by the governor, an influential alumnus of "Big State," one of the colleges Jesus is considering, so that he might persuade his son to sign with the governor's college. If successful, he'll get an early release from prison. While seemingly a sound plan, it turns haywire due to the strained relationship between Jesus (who resents his father for killing his mother) and Jake. Upon his first moments outside of prison, Jake contacts his daughter, Mary Shuttlesworth ([[Zelda Harris]]), who is happy to see him. Mary invites her father to the apartment where she and Jesus now live, having moved out of their Uncle Bubba's place. When Jesus returns home from school, he is unhappy to see his father. Refusing to look him in the eye, he tells his sister to get rid of the "stranger" in their living room. Jesus later agrees to meet with his father at an alternative location away from Mary. Throughout the movie, Jake tries to persuade Jesus to attend "Big State" with seemingly no success. Eventually, he divulges the deal set up by the governor. However, Jesus appears unsympathetic to his father's situation. Flashbacks illustrate the younger Jesus' gruelling basketball training under his father, and the night an argument between Jake and Jesus escalated into violence, resulting in Jake accidentally killing Jake's mother after she intervened. Jake reveals to Jesus the origin of the first name which embarrassed Jesus in childhood: Jake tells his son he named him not after [[Jesus Christ]] but after basketball player [[Earl Monroe]], who had the nicknames "Jesus" (which the white media changed to "Black Jesus"). Intertwined with the story of the Shuttlesworth family is the sub-plot of Dakota Barns ([[Milla Jovovich]]), a prostitute who stays in the room next to Jake in the run-down hotel, which the warden has booked for him. Dakota is being abused by her procurer and companion, Sweetness. Jake overhears the violence through the thin walls. Throughout the film, Jake is seen helping clean Dakota's wounds, and Jake gives Dakota some of his money to be used for his expenses during his week out of prison. He also develops a romantic relationship with her. Dakota is seen in one of the final scenes of the movie taking a Greyhound bus away from [[New York City]]. Jesus is tempted with offers of cash and women on recruiting visits to big time basketball programs. He also considers declaring the [[NBA]] in order to play professionally sooner and immediately lift himself and his sister out of poverty. Jake finally challenges Jesus to a game of one-on-one basketball, the winner being the first player to score 11. If Jake wins, Jesus will sign a letter of intent to play for "Big State" and if Jesus wins, he can make his own decision. After a competitive start, Jake tires during the course of the game and Jake wins, 11-5. Jake gives the letter of intent to his son, who casts it to the ground. AS Jake is collected for transportation back to Attica, he turns to Jesus and says, "Let me tell you something, son: You get that hatred out your heart, or you'll end up just another nigger...like your father." Ultimately, Jesus decides to sign to play for "Big State." However, the governor does not give Jake the promised reduction, and Jake's work-release is fabricated in the media as an escape from prison before being recaptured. Jake ultimately finds freedom by casting away his dreams and burdens to his son, Jesus, symbolized by the throwing of his old basketball over the prison wall and magically onto the Big State court where Jesus is practicing alone. Jesus clutches the ball, knowing it is a message of hope from his father. ==Cast== {{div col|colwidth=22em}} * [[Denzel Washington]] as Jake Shuttlesworth * [[Ray Allen]] as Jesus Shuttlesworth **[[Jade Yorker]] as Jesus Shuttlesworth (age 12) * [[Milla Jovovich]] as Dakota Barns * [[John Turturro]] as Coach Billy Sunday * [[Rosario Dawson]] as Lala Bonilla * [[Jim Brown]] as Spivey * Joseph Lyle Taylor as Crudup * [[Hill Harper]] as Coleman "Booger" Sykes ** Shortee Reed as Coleman "Booger" Sykes (age 12) * [[Zelda Harris]] as Mary Shuttlesworth ** Quinn Harris as Mary Shuttlesworth (age 6) * [[Ned Beatty]] as Warden Marcel Wyatt * [[Bill Nunn]] as Uncle Bubba * [[Thomas Jefferson Byrd]] as Sweetness * [[Roger Guenveur Smith]] as Big Time Willie * [[Lonette McKee]] as Martha Shuttlesworth * [[Travis Best]] as Sip * [[Walter McCarty]] as Mance * [[Kim Director]] as Lynn * [[John Wallace (basketball)|John Wallace]] as Lonnie * [[Rick Fox]] as Chick Deagan * [[Leonard Roberts]] as D'Andre Mackey * [[Jennifer Esposito]] as Ms. Janus * [[Chasey Lain]] as Buffy (listed as Tiffany Jones) * [[Jill Kelly (actress)|Jill Kelly]] as Suzie * Al Palagonia as Dom Pagnotti {{div col end}} ==Production== Filming took place between July and September 1997. Locations included [[Coney Island, Brooklyn]], [[Cabrini–Green|Cabrini–Green housing projects]] in [[Chicago, Illinois]], [[Elon University]], [[Charlotte, North Carolina]], and [[Los Angeles, California]]. For the role of Jesus, Lee had drawn up a list of every NBA player who could pass for a high school senior. [[Kobe Bryant]] was the original choice to portray Jesus Shuttlesworth, but after shooting several air balls that resulted in a brutal playoff loss to the Utah Jazz in the [[1997 NBA Playoffs]], he planned an extensive workout plan that would help maintain his strength throughout the duration of the longer NBA seasons. Lee found [[Tracy McGrady]] too reserved and was not impressed by [[Allen Iverson]]'s performance. Management for [[Kevin Garnett]] and [[Stephon Marbury]] wanted a guarantee that one or the other would be offered the part. [[Travis Best]], [[Walter McCarty]], and [[Rick Fox]] also auditioned, and Lee cast them in supporting roles. Lee approached Allen during halftime of a Bucks-[[New York Knicks|Knicks]] game, ultimately offering him the role of Jesus. Allen had never acted before, and he trained with an acting coach for eight weeks prior to filming.{{cite web|url=http://thisdistractedglobe.com/2008/05/12/he-got-game-1998-2/ |title=He Got Game (1998) |publisher=Thisdistractedglobe.com |date= |accessdate=2010-08-19}} NBA players [[Shaquille O'Neal]], [[Reggie Miller]], [[Bill Walton]], [[Scottie Pippen]], [[Michael Jordan]], and [[Charles Barkley]], [[Syracuse University]] coach [[Jim Boeheim]], NBA coaches [[Rick Pitino]] and [[George Karl]] and broadcaster [[Dick Vitale]] made cameo appearances at one point early in the film.{{cite video|author= |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=iGW-36kQzNo |title=Jesus Shuttlesworth |publisher=[[YouTube]] |date= |accessdate=2010-08-19 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130227185927/https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=iGW-36kQzNo |archivedate=February 27, 2013 }} Former football legend [[Jim Brown]] also appears as one of Jake's parole officers, assigned to keep tabs on him while he's away from the prison. ==Release== ===Box office=== ''He Got Game'' was produced on an estimated $25 million budget.{{Citation needed|date=September 2011}} In the opening weekend of its release, it was shown on 1,319 screens, and took in $7,610,663 at the U.S. box offices debuting at #1.[http://www.boxofficemojo.com/weekend/chart/?yr=1998&wknd=18&p=.htm Weekend Box Office Results for May 1-3, 1998 - Box Office Mojo] It eventually grossed a total of $21,554,585.00, which was a box office flop considering it fell short of its $25 million budget. ===Critical response=== Response to the film was largely favorable, with review aggregator [[Rotten Tomatoes]] showing it receiving 80% favorable reviews, praising Lee's artfulness, commentary, and honest connection to human characters. Negative reviews focused their criticism on the film's length and Lee's overindulgence, with ''[[Time Out London]]'' writing, "Most scenes play too long, with a surplus of ideas, textures, tones and characters, and after 134 minutes it's clear Lee's problem with closure hasn't gone away."{{cite web |url=http://www.timeout.com/film/dvd/98441.html |title=He Got Game Review. Movie Reviews - Film - Time Out London |publisher=Timeout.com |date=2005-04-06 |accessdate=2010-08-19 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070311035025/http://www.timeout.com/film/dvd/98441.html |archivedate=2007-03-11 |df= }}{{cite web|url=http://www.rottentomatoes.com/m/he_got_game/ |title=He Got Game Movie Reviews, Pictures |publisher=Rotten Tomatoes |date= |accessdate=2010-08-19}} [[Roger Ebert]] gave the film three-and-a-half-stars, and called it Lee's best film since ''[[Malcolm X (1992 film)|Malcolm X]]''. He was particularly encouraged by Lee's determination not to adhere to typical conventions.{{cite news|url=http://rogerebert.suntimes.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/19980501/REVIEWS/805010304/1023 |title=He Got Game :: rogerebert.com :: Reviews |publisher=Rogerebert.suntimes.com |date= |accessdate=2010-08-19}} Both Ray Allen and Washington drew praise for their performances,{{cite news|author=|url=http://www.variety.com/review/VE1117477426.html?categoryid=31&cs=1&query=he+got+game |title=He Got Game Review - Read Variety's Analysis Of The Movie He Got Game |publisher=Variety.com |date= 1998-04-27|accessdate=2010-08-19}} with Roger Ebert writing that Allen "is that rarity, an athlete who can act," and ''Slate'' magazine writing that Washington's performance was "gorgeously underplayed".{{cite web |last=Edelstein |first=David |url=http://slate.msn.com/id/3252 |title=He Got Balls - By David Edelstein - Slate Magazine |publisher=Slate.msn.com |date=1998-05-03 |accessdate=2010-08-19 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090125225131/http://slate.msn.com/id/3252 |archivedate=2009-01-25 |df= }} ESPN's review pointed out factual flaws in the story: "...coaches aren't allowed to discuss potential recruits until after the signing period. Come on, Spike. (And while we're at it, players aren't allowed to visit a college one week before the signing deadline; Jesus couldn't live alone with his sister without both of them being thrown in a foster home; and there's NO WAY IN HELL that Jesus wouldn't have just turned pro if he was that good and that broke.)" [http://sports.espn.go.com/espn/page2/story?page=simmons/movies/hegotgame Simmons, 'Review - He Got Game'], ESPN sports ==Soundtrack== {{further|He Got Game (soundtrack)}} The soundtrack for ''He Got Game'' was composed of numerous orchestral pieces by [[Aaron Copland]] with songs created by [[Public Enemy (band)|Public Enemy]]. It was released by [[Def Jam Recordings|Def Jam]] on April 21, 1998. ==Awards and nominations== ;[[Acapulco Black Film Festival|1999 Acapulco Black Film Festival]] * Best Actor — Denzel Washington (nominated) * Best Director — Spike Lee (nominated) * Best Screenplay — Spike Lee (nominated) * Best Film (nominated) * Best Soundtrack (nominated) ;[[NAACP Image Award|1999 NAACP Image Awards]] * Outstanding Lead Actor in a Motion Picture — Denzel Washington (nominated) * Outstanding Youth Actor/Actress — [[Zelda Harris]] (nominated) * Outstanding Motion Picture (nominated) ;[[MTV Movie Awards|1999 MTV Movie Awards]] * MTV Movie Award Best Breakthrough Male Performance — Ray Allen (nominated) ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== {{wikiquote}} * {{IMDb title|0124718|He Got Game}} * {{allrovi movie|162469|He Got Game}} * {{mojo title|hegotgame|He Got Game}} * {{rotten-tomatoes|he_got_game|He Got Game}} {{Spike Lee}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:He Got Game}} [[Category:1998 films]] [[Category:1990s drama films]] [[Category:1990s sports films]] [[Category:Films about interracial romance]] [[Category:40 Acres & A Mule Filmworks films]] [[Category:American basketball films]] [[Category:American drama films]] [[Category:American sports films]] [[Category:English-language films]] [[Category:Films directed by Spike Lee]] [[Category:Films set in Brooklyn]] [[Category:Films shot in Illinois]] [[Category:Films shot in New York City]] [[Category:Films shot in New Jersey]] [[Category:Films shot in North Carolina]] [[Category:Films shot in Virginia]] [[Category:Hood films]] [[Category:Prison films]] [[Category:Screenplays by Spike Lee]] [[Category:Touchstone Pictures films]] [[Category:Uxoricide in fiction]] [[Category:American films]] [[Category:African-American films]]

revision.text:
{{About|the [[A-League]] stadium in Adelaide|the [[South Australian National Football League|SANFL]] stadium in Adelaide also known as Coopers Stadium|Norwood Oval}} {{Use dmy dates|date=February 2014}} {{Use Australian English|date=February 2014}} {{Infobox venue | stadium_name = Hindmarsh Stadium[http://www.coopersstadium.com.au/ Coopers Stadium] | image = [[File:HindmarshStadium.JPG|300px]] | nickname = Coopers Stadium | location = Holden Street,
[[Hindmarsh, South Australia|Hindmarsh]], [[South Australia]] 5007 | coordinates = {{coord|34|54|27|S|138|34|8|E|display=it}} | built = 1960 | opened = 1960 | renovated = February 2000 | owner = [[South Australian Government]] | operator = Adelaide Venue Management Corporation[http://www.avmc.com.au/ Adelaide Venue Management Corporation] | seating_capacity = 16,500[http://www.austadiums.com/stadiums/stadiums.php?id=54 Coopers Stadium (Hindmarsh Stadium) | Austadiums] | record_attendance = 18,430 ([[Italy national under-21 football team|Italy]] vs [[Nigeria national under-23 football team|Nigeria]], [[Football at the 2000 Summer Olympics – Men's tournament|2000 Olympic Games]]) | tenants = [[West Adelaide SC]] ([[National Soccer League|NSL]]) (1977–1999)
[[Adelaide City]] ([[National Soccer League|NSL]]) (1986–2004)
[[Adelaide Rams]] ([[National Rugby League|NRL]]) (1998)
[[Adelaide Black Falcons]] (2000-2012)
[[Adelaide United FC|Adelaide United]] ([[National Soccer League|NSL]]/[[A-League]]) (2003–present) | dimensions = 120 x 80 metres |}} The '''Hindmarsh Stadium''' (currently known as the '''Coopers Stadium''' due to sponsorship from the Adelaide-based [[Coopers Brewery]]{{citation|url=http://www.coopers.com.au/about-us/news.aspx#Coopers_Wins_Naming_Rights_To_Hindmarsh_Stadium|title=Coopers Wins Naming Rights To Hindmarsh Stadium|publisher=''[[Coopers Brewery]]''|date=1 July 2013|accessdate=1 July 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140203232959/http://www.coopers.com.au/about-us/news.aspx/#Coopers_Wins_Naming_Rights_To_Hindmarsh_Stadium|archivedate=3 February 2014|df=dmy-all}}) is a [[multi-purpose stadium]] in [[Hindmarsh, South Australia|Hindmarsh]], an inner western suburb of [[Adelaide]], [[South Australia]]. It is the home of the Australian [[A-League]] team, [[Adelaide United FC|Adelaide United]]. The stadium has a capacity of 16,500, of which 15,000 is seated. Home team [[Adelaide United FC|Adelaide United]] regularly fill this capacity, and averaged crowds of over 12,000 to its matches during the [[A-League 2006-07|2006-07 Season]] and [[A-League 2007-08|2007-08 Season]]. United used the stadium for its home matches in the [[AFC Champions League 2008|2008 AFC Asian Champions League]], the [[AFC Champions League 2010|2010 AFC Asian Champions League]], and the [[AFC Champions League 2012|2012 AFC Asian Champions League]]. ==History== Built in 1960, the stadium stands on the site that was once Hindmarsh Oval which housed the [[West Torrens Football Club]] of the [[South Australian National Football League|SANFL]] from 1905 until 1921, when the team moved to nearby [[Thebarton Oval]] which would remain its home until 1989. During World War I the Patriotic Football League, a group of SANFL clubs that wanted to continue playing football during the war played many games at the venue. The 1916 Patriotic Football League Grand Final was held at the ground between {{AFL Por}} and {{SANFL WT}} with Port Adelaide winning 7.11 (53) to 1.13 (19).{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article59827704 |title=FOOTBALL. |newspaper=[[The Mail (Adelaide)]] |volume=5, |issue=222 |location=South Australia |date=19 August 1916 |accessdate=23 January 2017 |page=5 |via=National Library of Australia}} The [[Football Federation of South Australia|Soccer Association of South Australia]] owned land on a former brick pit on [[Torrens Road, Adelaide|Torrens Road]] at [[Brompton, South Australia|Brompton]] named Rowley Park which was located only 5 km from the [[City of Adelaide|city]], and the original plan was for the land to be the home of Soccer in SA as the site formed a natural bowl. However, the Soccer Association had received negative press regarding its failure to grow grass on the site. Rowley Park also had a tendency to flood during winter as the bottom of "The Brick Pit" was below the level of the [[water table]] which made playing soccer virtually impossible. The land was eventually leased to a group of [[Dirt track racing|speedway]] drivers and would become the famous [[Rowley Park Speedway]] which ran from December 1949 until it closed in April 1979. The land was eventually sold and is now the Kym Bonython housing estate, named for the speedway's long time promoter [[Kym Bonython]]. When it became obvious to the Soccer Association that Rowley Park would be unsuitable as a soccer venue they obtained a lease on Hindmarsh Oval from the Hindmarsh Council. The old Hindmarsh Oval was developed over the years into a rectangular stadium capable of holding 15,000 with a single tier grandstand built in 1960 that held approximately 2,000 while 6 light towers for night games (plus another 8 smaller light towers on the grandstand roof) were installed during the mid-1970s. Other than the grandstand, the ground was all terracing surrounding the playing surface. This changed in 1996 when seats were installed on the eastern side of the ground. Along with the [[Kensington Oval, Adelaide|Olympic Sports Field]], Hindmarsh became one of two Adelaide venues in the then new but now-defunct [[National Soccer League]] in [[1977 National Soccer League|1977]]. Hindmarsh was the home ground of the [[Adelaide City|Adelaide City Zebras]] (who also played games at the Sports Field), and later the home ground for [[West Adelaide SC|West Adelaide Hellas]]. Hindmarsh would eventually become the sole Adelaide NSL venue during the late 1980s. In 1986 Hindmarsh stadium hosted the first leg of the NSL Grand Final between Adelaide City and [[Sydney Olympic Football Club|Sydney Olympic]]. Unfortunately for Adelaide fans Olympic won 1-0. Adelaide would go on to win the 2nd leg in Sydney 3-1 and become NSL Champions. Hindmarsh again hosted the NSL Grand Final (this time a single game) in 1994-95 when Adelaide City faced the [[Mark Viduka]] led [[Melbourne Knights FC|Melbourne Knights]]. In front of a packed house of over 16,000 the Knights defeated the Zebras 2-0. As soccer was generally played to smaller crowds during the 1970s and 80's, Hindmarsh became a regular host of the [[Socceroos]] in some of their international matches, with Adelaide-based players such as [[Robert Zabica]], [[Alex Tobin]], and the Vidmar brothers [[Aurelio Vidmar|Aurelio]] and [[Tony Vidmar|Tony]] all playing prominent roles. Hindmarsh Stadium not only hosted soccer matches but also hosted [[Rugby Union]] and [[Rugby League]]. In 1992 the [[New Zealand All Blacks]] played an exhibition game against a [[South Australia Rugby Union|South Australian 'Select']] team which included former [[Australian Wallabies|Wallabies]] [[Lock (rugby union)|Lock]] and current day author/media personality [[Peter FitzSimons]]. The All Blacks, including goal kicking [[Stand-off (rugby union)|Stand-off]] [[Grant Fox]] who would retire the following year as the All Blacks highest ever point scorer, ran out easy winners while FitzSimons, playing up to the crowd by humorously claiming innocence, was sent off midway through the second half after numerous infringements. At the time this made FitzSimons the only Wallaby (although his international career had finished by the time of the match) to ever be sent off in a match against the All Blacks. In 1996 as part of the rebuilding of the venue before the [[2000 Summer Olympic Games]], the original single tier grandstand with its wooden bench seats was demolished and replaced by the current two tier structure. The terracing on the opposite wing was also removed and replaced by seating. When the ground was rebuilt before the Olympics only the new grandstand would remain in place. [[File:Hindmarsh Stadium 6.jpg|thumb|[[National Rugby League]] match between the [[Cronulla-Sutherland Sharks]] and [[North Queensland Cowboys]] at Hindmarsh Stadium on 19 April 2009]] In 1998 the short lived [[National Rugby League]] team the [[Adelaide Rams]] used Hindmarsh for their last 4 home games of the [[1998 NRL season]]. The Rams début at the venue was a success when they thumped the [[Balmain Tigers]] 52-0 in front of 7,351 fans. The Rams would end up 2-2 at Hindmarsh after defeating the [[Auckland Warriors]], but losing to [[Manly Sea Eagles|Manly-Warringah]] and [[North Sydney Bears|North Sydney]]. The Rams were to continue using Hindmarsh as their home ground in the [[1999 NRL season]] giving them a rectangular venue suited to league rather than an oval as was their previous home, the [[Adelaide Oval]]. However the team was wound up by owners [[News Limited|News Ltd]] only weeks before the start of the 1999 season. Hindmarsh Stadium was one of the venues chosen to host preliminary matches for the [[Football at the 2000 Summer Olympics – Men's tournament|men's soccer]] during the 2000 Olympics held in [[Sydney]]. This saw the stadium receive almost a complete rebuild which brought it to its present status. The field was lengthened from 110 to 120 metres to be able to also accommodate both rugby league and rugby union which used longer field dimensions (though the minimum field length of a union field including in-goal areas is actually 120 metres so shorter than desirable in-goals are required), the six old light towers were replaced with four television standard ones (one in each corner with lights also on the front edge of the grandstand roof) and the former terracing was now all seated, uncovered stands with only the grandstand built in the mid-1990s remaining in place. During the Olympics, temporary stands were erected in the corners of the stadium to bring capacity up to 20,000. Hosting matches from Groups A and B, the recorded attendance at Hindmarsh was set at 18,340 when [[Italy national under-21 football team|Italy]] drew 1-1 [[Nigeria national under-23 football team|Nigeria]] on 19 September 2000. Other [[soccer]] played in the stadium in the past include several international matches, including most of the games played in the [[2004 OFC Nations Cup]] - an event where the Socceroos began their qualifying campaign for the [[2006 FIFA World Cup]]. In 2007 the venue hosted the first two rounds of the [[Australia national under-23 football team|Olyroos]] campaign as they qualified for the [[2008 Summer Olympics]]. With the rise in the sports popularity in Australia, Hindmarsh is rarely used these days by the Socceroos other than for training purposes or matches against lower ranked countries such as those from the [[Pacific Ocean|Pacific]] islands. International matches now generally take place at larger capacity venues such as [[Sydney]]'s 84,000 seat [[ANZ Stadium]], [[Brisbane]]'s 52,500 seat [[Suncorp Stadium]], or the largest stadium in the [[Southern Hemisphere]], the 100,024 capacity [[Melbourne Cricket Ground]]. Though with the redevelopment of the [[Adelaide Oval]] to a world class, [[FIFA]] compliant 53,583 capacity stadium (50,083 seated), there is renewed speculation that the Socceroos will return to Adelaide for high-profile international matches. On 15 April 2006 on a Saturday night the stadium hosted its first NRL match since the Rams final home game in 1998 when the Sydney-based [[Penrith Panthers]] played that year's NRL Grand Finalist the [[Melbourne Storm]]. With 7,017 fans in attendance the Storm ran out easy 40-18 winners with emerging rugby league superstar [[Greg Inglis]] scoring 3 tries for Melbourne.[http://stats.rleague.com/rl/scorers/games/2006/200604151927.html Penrith v Melbourne stats] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120204064320/http://stats.rleague.com/rl/scorers/games/2006/200604151927.html |date=4 February 2012 }} It was a home match for the Panthers who brought the game to Adelaide due to renovations being completed at their usual home, [[Penrith Park]] in western Sydney. The Stadium's Record attendance outside of the 2000 Olympic Games is 17,000 at the [[AFC Champions League 2008|2008 AFC Champions League]] [[AFC Champions League 2008#Final|Final Second leg]] between Adelaide United and [[Gamba Osaka]] of [[Japan]]. Adelaide lost 2-0, but still became tournament runners up. This remains Adelaide United's record attendance at Hindmarsh. On 3 October 2008 it was announced by the SA Government Minister for Recreation and Sport [[Michael Wright (Australian politician)|Michael Wright]] coach [[Ricky Stuart]], head coach of Sydney-based NRL team the [[Cronulla-Sutherland Sharks]], that the Sharks would play three NRL home games at Hindmarsh over 3 years starting from 2009. The first of those was against the [[North Queensland Cowboys]] on 19 April 2009. On a sunny autumn day the Cowboys defeated the Sharks 34-10 in front of 8,547 fans, the record crowd for a rugby league match at Hindmarsh. Unfortunately for NRL fans in Adelaide it was announced early in the [[2010 NRL season|2010 season]] that Cronulla had been allowed by the SA Government to pull out of their contract. Cronulla's official reasons were wanting to concentrate on their home fans by not taking home games away from [[Endeavour Field|Toyota Stadium]]. The NRL return to Adelaide in [[2010 NRL season|2010]] when another Sydney based club [[Canterbury-Bankstown Bulldogs]] played a home game at the [[Adelaide Oval]] instead of Hindmarsh against the Melbourne Storm. The Bulldogs had planned to make the Adelaide Oval their 'other' home, returning in [[2011 NRL season|2011]], again against the Storm, but this was also abandoned after just two years.[http://www.couriermail.com.au/sport/nrl/adelaide-left-to-bulldogs/story-e6frep5x-1225793112166 Adelaide left to Bulldogs | Courier Mail] The venue took host to the inaugural [[2014 FFA Cup Final|FFA cup final]] on 16 December 2014 which saw [[Adelaide United FC|Adelaide United]] face [[Perth Glory FC|Perth Glory]].{{Cite web|url=https://www.adelaideunited.com.au/news/adelaide-triumph-inaugural-cup-final|title=Adelaide triumph in inaugural Cup Final|website=Adelaide United|language=en|access-date=2018-04-17}} United were 1-0 victors with an attendance of 16,142. {{wide image|Adl utd stadium.jpg|900px|align-cap=center|Panorama View of Hindmarsh Stadium, [[Adelaide United]] vs [[Perth Glory]] in 2009}} {{wide image|Hindmarsh Stadium Panorama from Away End, October 2016.jpg|900px|align-cap=center|Panorama of Hindmarsh Stadium from the away end before [[Adelaide United]] v [[Melbourne Victory]], October 2016}} {{-}} ==2000 Olympic Games== Hindmarsh Stadium hosted seven games of the [[2000 Summer Olympics|2000]] [[Olympic Games]] [[Football at the 2000 Summer Olympics – Men's tournament|Men's Football tournament]] including a Quarter final match. The stadium's all-time attendance record of 18,430 was set during the Group A match between Italy and Nigeria. {| class="wikitable" style="text-align: left;" width="90%" |- !Date !Time ([[Time in Australia|ACST]]) !Team #1 !Result !Team #2 !Round !Attendance |- |13 September 2000 || 18:30 || {{fbu|23|Nigeria}} || style="text-align:center;"|3–3 || {{fbu|23|Honduras}} || Group A || style="text-align:center;"| 13,386 |- |14 September 2000 || 18:30 || {{fbu|23|South Korea}} || style="text-align:center;"|0–3 || {{fbu|23|Spain}} || Group B || style="text-align:center;"| 14,060 |- |16 September 2000 || 18:30 || {{fbu|21|Italy}} || style="text-align:center;"|3–1 || {{fbu|23|Honduras}} || Group A || style="text-align:center;"| 18,301 |- |17 September 2000 || 18:30 || {{fbu|23|South Korea}} || style="text-align:center;"|1–0 || {{fbu|23|Morocco}} || Group B || style="text-align:center;"| 12,753 |- |19 September 2000 || 18:30 || {{fbu|21|Italy}} || style="text-align:center;"|1–1 || {{fbu|23|Nigeria}} || Group A || style="text-align:center;"| 18,430 |- |20 September 2000 || 18:30 || {{fbu|23|South Korea}} || style="text-align:center;"|1–0 || {{fbu|23|Chile}} || Group B || style="text-align:center;"| 16,309 |- |23 September 2000 || 18:30 || {{fbu|23|United States}} || style="text-align:center;"|1–1 (5–4 [[penalty shootout (football)|pen.]]) || {{fbu|23|Japan}} || Quarter final 1 || style="text-align:center;"| 18,345 |} ==Rugby League== Hindmarsh Stadium has hosted six top grade rugby league matches.[http://www.rugbyleagueproject.org/venues/hindmarsh-oval/results.html Hindmarsh Stadium at Rugby League Project] {| class="wikitable" |- style="background:#bdb76b;" ! In 1990 the team has won the [[Togolese Championnat National]].http://www.rsssf.com/tablest/togochamp.html ==Stadium== Their home stadium is [[Guanha Usdao Pesihu]]. ==Achievements== *'''[[Togolese Championnat National]]''' ::Champions (1): 1990 ==Performance in CAF competitions== * '''[[African Cup of Champions Clubs]]: 1 appearance''' ::[[1991 African Cup of Champions Clubs]] – First Round ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.weltfussballarchiv.com/club_profile.php?ID=14690] *[http://www.panapress.com/ifodje-d-Atakpame-champion-de-football-de-la-D2-togolaise--13-605515-18-lang2-index.html Team profile] {{Togolese Championnat National}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Ifodje Atakpame}} [[Category:Football clubs in Togo]] {{Togo-footyclub-stub}}

revision.text:
{{About|the game|other uses|Lapta (disambiguation)}} [[File:Игра_в_лапту.jpg|right|thumb|A lapta game being played in 2014]] [[File:Игра в лапту в России.jpg|thumb|An illustration of a group of men playing Lapta (circa 16th Century).]] '''Lapta''' ({{lang-ru|лапта́}}) is a [[Russia]]n [[bat and ball games|bat and ball game]] first known to be played in the 14th century.{{cite book |title=Baseball in Europe: a country by country history |last=Chetwynd |first=Josh |year=2008 |publisher=McFarland |location= |isbn= 9780786437245 |page=133 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=USi7PA151vIC&pg=PA133 |accessdate=2010-07-08}} Mentions of lapta have been found in medieval manuscripts, and balls and bats were found in the 14th-century layers during excavations in [[Novgorod]]. It is similar to [[cricket]], [[brännboll]], [[Rounders]], [[baseball]], [[oină]], [[:it:Tsan]] (Italy) and [[pesäpallo]]. ==Rules== The game is played outside on a field the size of half a [[football pitch]]{{cite book |title=Baseball in Europe: a country by country history |last=Chetwynd |first=Josh |year=2008 |publisher=McFarland |location= |isbn= 9780786437245 |page=313 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=USi7PA151vIC&pg=PA133 |accessdate=2010-07-08}} 20 x 25 [[sazhen]]s ({{convert|140|ft|m}} x {{convert|175|ft|m}}). There are 5 people on the field from the defending team, as well as pitcher/server. This pitcher server stands near the batter of the opposing team and hits a ball in the direction of the batter. The team that bats contains six people. Each hitter gets 2 chances to hit the ball over a 10m line. If they succeed at that, the runners can go to an endline at the other end of the pitch. If a player manages to run between the two endpoints, they get 2 points. A game lasts an hour, split into two equal halves. The edges of the field were marked with parallel lines, called ''salo''. The goal of the game is to hit the ball, served by a player of the opposite team, with the bat and send the ball as far as possible, then run across the field to the ''kon'' line, and if possible to run back to the ''gorod'' line. The running player should try to avoid being hit with the ball, which is thrown by the opposing team members. For successful runs, the team earns points. A team wins by either getting more points during the scheduled time or by having all its players complete runs. A description of lapta is given by [[Aleksandr Kuprin]]:
This folk game is one of the most interesting and useful games. Lapta requires resourcefulness, deep breathing, faithfulness to your group, attention, dexterity, fast running, good aiming and marksmanship, strong striking hands, and firm eternal confidence that you cannot be defeated. The lazy and cowardly have no place in this game.
==References== {{Reflist}} {{Team Sport}} [[Category:Ball games]] [[Category:Ball and bat games]] [[Category:Team sports]] [[Category:Russian folk games]] [[Category:Russian inventions]] [[Category:Sports originating in Russia]]
