[[Western Force]] ([[Super Rugby|SR]], [[Global Rapid Rugby|GRR]]) (2010–present)
[[Australia national soccer team|Australia national football team]]
[[Australia national rugby union team|Australia national rugby union team]] | website = [http://www.nibstadium.com.au/ nibstadium.com.au] | former_names = Loton Park
Members Equity Stadium
ME Bank Stadium | estimated_cost = }} '''Perth Oval''' (also known as '''nib Stadium''' under a [[naming rights]] agreement with [[nib Health Funds]]; will be known as '''HBF Park''' from 2019 under an agreement with [[HBF Health Fund|HBF]]{{Cite web|url=https://www.venueswest.wa.gov.au/news/perths-leading-rectangular-venue-to-be-renamed-hbf-park/|title=Perth's leading rectangular venue to be renamed HBF Park {{!}} VenuesWest|website=VenuesWest|language=en|access-date=2018-11-20}}) is a sports stadium in [[Perth]], the capital of the [[Australian states and territories|Australian state]] of [[Western Australia]]. Located close to [[Perth (suburb)|Perth's central business district]], the stadium currently has a maximum capacity of 20,500 people for sporting events and 25,000 people for concerts, with the ground's record attendance of 32,000 people set during an [[Ed Sheeran]] concert in 2015.{{cite web|title=Ed Sheeran Concert Breaks Record at nib Stadium|url=http://www.nibstadium.com.au/news/ed-sheeran-concert-breaks-record-at-nib-stadium/|publisher=Venues West|accessdate=4 December 2015}} The land on which the stadium was built was made a public reserve in 1904, with the main ground developed several years later. Perth Oval was the home ground of the [[East Perth Football Club]] in the [[West Australian Football League]] (WAFL) from 1910 until 2002, and hosted several of the competition's [[grand final]]s during that time. In 2004, the ground was redeveloped, altering it from an oval field to a rectangular field. The ground is currently home to two major professional sporting clubs: [[Perth Glory FC]], a [[Association football|soccer]] team competing in the [[A-League]], and the [[Western Force]], a [[rugby union]] team competing in the [[Global Rapid Rugby]] competition. The ground is also used by the [[WA Reds]], a semi-professional [[rugby league]] team competing in the [[S. G. Ball Cup]], as well as for concerts. ==Current use== The stadium is currently used for hosting sports events and concerts. ===Sport=== In sports mode the stadium has a capacity of around 20,500. [[Association football|Soccer]] club [[Perth Glory]] has played at the ground since 1996. The stadium is unusual among modern Australian stadiums for having a standing [[Terrace (stadium)|terrace]] at the northern end of the ground, called 'The Shed'. A breakaway group from the vocal [[Association football culture#Fans|supporters]] of the [[Perth Glory]] 'Shed', named 'Glory Fans United', are now situated in the Southern Stand. The ground has hosted rugby union team Western Force since 2010. The Force's move to the stadium led to a minor redevelopment of facilities at the ground, including an increase in capacity and improved lighting.{{cite web | url=http://www.rugbyweek.com/news/viewarticle.asp?id=22287 | title=The Force gets new home stadium for 2010 | work=Rugby Week | date=25 September 2009 | accessdate=8 July 2011}} For 2008 the stadium hosted [[WA Reds]] home matches in the [[Bundaberg Red Cup]]. Since 2009, there have been annual [[NRL]] games played at the oval, generally as [[South Sydney Rabbitohs]] home games, with the [[Manly Warringah Sea Eagles]] joining in 2016. The stadium has housed the administrative facilities of the [[Western Australia Rugby League]] since 2003.http://stats.rleague.com/rl/venues/perth.html In 2015, the stadium hosted a [[2018 FIFA World Cup qualification (AFC)|2018 FIFA World Cup qualifier]] between the [[Australia national soccer team|Australia]] and [[Bangladesh national football team|Bangladesh]], the first A-international in Perth in over a decade.{{cite web|url=http://www.socceroos.com.au/article/socceroos-to-play-world-cup-qualifier-in-perth/hk3ff72t7u951qz3uivzbp4db|title=Socceroos to play World Cup qualifier against Bangladesh in Perth|work=socceroos.com.au|accessdate=15 October 2016}} ===Concerts=== The capacity for [[concerts]] is now over 25,000.{{cite web | url=http://au.news.yahoo.com/thewest/entertainment/a/-/music/9799567/foo-fighters-to-start-oz-tour-in-perth/ | title=Foo Fighters to start Oz tour in Perth | work=The West Australian | date=8 July 2011 | accessdate=8 July 2011 | last=Collins|first= Simon | last2=Zuel|first2= Bernard}} A record 32,000 crowd attended the [[Ed Sheeran]] concert in 2015. ==History== ===Early history=== The land on which the stadium is built was known as '''Loton's Paddock''' after the previous owner [[William Loton]], [[Lord Mayor of Perth]].{{cite web|url=http://www.vincent.wa.gov.au/agenda/whatsnew/Media/Perth%20Oval%20update2.pdf|title=New public land surrounding Perth Oval to be co-named after original|date=9 April 2003|publisher=[[Town of Vincent]]|accessdate=28 April 2009}} The Paddock had been reclaimed from part of Stone's Lake, which was part of a lake system known as [[Perth Wetlands|The Great Lakes District]] which included [[Lake Monger]] and [[Herdsman Lake]]. Loton sold the land to the [[City of Perth]] in 1904 with the purpose of providing recreation for the residents of the area. After the 2004 redevelopment, part of the ground reverted to public open space and the original name, Loton Park was re-applied, to honour Loton, and Yoordgoorading as a reference to the original Indigenous inhabitants of the land.{{cite news | url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article84575677 | title=A new recreation ground - handing over the titles | work=The Daily News | date=8 November 1904 | accessdate=29 November 2013|via=National Library of Australia}} In the early 1930s large white entry gates were built on the north west corner of the ground. These have since been heritage listed. ===Soccer=== [[File:Perth v North Queensland.jpg|right|thumb|225px|Perth Glory and North Queensland Fury in 2009 during an [[A-League]] match.]] [[Association football|Soccer]] was an early tenant at Loton Park, playing regular matches as early as 1903, when over 2,000 spectators attended a Charity Cup match between Olympic FC and Civil Service.{{cite web|url=http://www.amnet.net.au/~daveiza/royals/po.html |title=Brief History of Perth Oval |publisher=Fight On East Perth|accessdate=28 April 2009}} In 1905 the land was offered to the WA British Football Association for £2000, but the asking price was considered too high. Perth Oval was the scene of a humiliation in 1927 when the [[Western Australia state football team|WA State]] team were thrashed 11–3 by [[Bohemians 1905|Bohemians]], a team representing [[Czechoslovakia]].{{cite web|url=http://www.oleole.com/blogs/bohemians1905/posts/why-is-there-a-kangaroo-in-the-emblem-of-the-central-european-club|title=why is there a kangaroo in the emblem of the central european club???|date=15 May 2008|publisher=oleole.com|accessdate=28 April 2009}} Prior to the 2004 redevelopment, Perth Oval was oval-shaped, and when [[Perth Glory FC]] entered the [[National Soccer League|NSL]] in 1996, temporary stands were moved onto the pitch to get supporters closer to the action. After playing in these conditions for four years, it became apparent that the Glory would need their own rectangular stadium and after Glory's proposed redevelopment of [[Leederville Oval]] was rejected, the [[Town of Vincent]] completely overhauled the ground into a rectangular stadium. Perth Glory are now major tenants of this stadium and continue play their home games at Perth Oval. Perth Oval also hosted the 2014 [[W-League (Australia)|W-League]] Semi-Final and Grand Final matches involving [[Perth Glory FC W-League|Perth Glory Women]]. 2015 saw the return of the [[Australia national football team|Socceroos]] to Perth after a 10-year absence, with a 5–0 [[2018 FIFA World Cup qualification (AFC)|2018 FIFA World Cup Qualifier]] win against [[Bangladesh national football team|Bangladesh]] on 3 September, in front of a 19,495-strong crowd.{{cite web |url=http://www.socceroos.com.au/matchcentre/Australia-v-Bangladesh/800453 |title=Five-star Socceroos overwhelm Bangladesh |publisher=Football Federation Australia |work=socceroos.com.au |accessdate=3 September 2015}} The following year on 1 September the [[Australia national football team|Socceroos]] returned for another World Cup Qualifier against [[Iraq national football team|Iraq]], with 18,923 in attendance. ==== Men's International Soccer==== {| class="wikitable" |- style="background:#bdb76b;" ! Game !! Date !! Team !! Result !! Team !! Attendance !! Part of |- |1 || 3 September 2015 || align=right|{{fb-rt|AUS}} || align=center|[[2018 FIFA World Cup qualification – AFC Second Round#Group B|5–0]] || {{fb|Bangladesh}} || 19,495 || [[2018 FIFA World Cup qualification – AFC Second Round|2018 World Cup Qualification – Second Round]] |- |2 || 1 September 2016 || align=right|{{fb-rt|AUS}} || align=center|[[2018 FIFA World Cup qualification – AFC Third Round#Group B|2–0]] || {{fb|IRQ}} || 18,923 || [[2018 FIFA World Cup qualification – AFC Second Round|2018 World Cup Qualification – Third Round]] |} ==== Women's International Soccer==== {| class="wikitable" |- style="background:#bdb76b;" ! Game !! Date !! Team !! Result !! Team !! Attendance !! Part of |- |1 || 26 March 2018 || align="right" |{{fbw-rt|AUS}}|| align="center" |5–0 ||{{fbw|THA}}||7,549{{Cite web|url=https://matildas.footballaustralia.com.au/news/social-media-reaction-classy-matildas-thumping-win-perth|title=Social media reaction to classy Matildas' thumping win in Perth|website=Matildas|language=en|access-date=2018-07-04}} |[[Exhibition game|Friendly]] |} [[File:Perth Oval Panorama January 2017.jpg|thumb|800px|centre|Perth Oval Panorama following a [[Perth Glory]] match, January 2017]] ===Australian rules football=== [[File:CBC Footy Team on Perth Oval 1919.jpg|right|thumb|225px|Christian Brothers College players walking onto Perth Oval in 1919]] [[Australian rules football]] club [[East Perth Football Club]] moved to Perth Oval from [[Wellington Square, Perth|Wellington Square]] in 1910,{{cite web|url=http://register.heritage.wa.gov.au/PDF_Files/P-Q%20-%20A-D/Perth%20Oval%20(I-AD).PDF|title=Register of Heritage Places|publisher=Heritage Council of Western Australia|accessdate=28 April 2009}} and played at the ground until [[1999 Westar Rules season|1999]] except [[1940 WANFL season|in 1940]] due to a dispute with the [[City of Perth|Perth City Council]] over rents,"Football: City Council Grounds for Practice"; ''[[The West Australian]]'', 12 March 1940, p. 9 and [[1988 WAFL season|in 1988]] [[1989 WAFL season|and 1989]] when the WAFL attempted an unsuccessful move to [[WACA Ground|the WACA]]. After the Royals played their last match at the ground, they permanently moved away in 2003.{{cite web|url=http://www.eastperthfc.com.au/history|title=History|publisher=[[East Perth Football Club]]|accessdate=28 April 2009}} In 1956 the F.D. Book Stand was built as part of East Perth Football Club’s golden jubilee celebrations. It was named after administrator [[Fred Book]], who was instrumental in ensuring Perth Oval stayed as a sporting ground during [[World War II]]. The ground was briefly used as a home base for East Perth's WAFL rivals [[West Perth Football Club|West Perth]] and [[Perth Football Club|Perth]]. Six [[West Australian Football League]] Grand Finals were played at Perth Oval, the first being in 1912 and the last in 1935.{{cite web|url=http://www.wafl.com.au/games|title=History|publisher=[[West Australian Football League]]|accessdate=30 April 2009}} ===Cricket=== Perth Oval was home to [[Western Australian Grade Cricket]] teams North Perth and University. North Perth played at the oval between 1910 and 1975 and University between 1913 and 1929. ===Rugby union=== Rugby was played at Perth Oval as early as 1905.{{cite web | url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article57202213 | title=Rugby Notes | work=The Sunday Times | date=21 May 1905 | accessdate=8 May 2011|via=National Library of Australia}} The ground has occasionally been used by the Western Australian Rugby Union to host state league finals matches at least as far back as 1940.{{cite web | url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article46737760 | title=Rugby - Matches at Perth Oval | work=The West Australian | date=13 September 1940 | accessdate=8 July 2011|via=National Library of Australia}} [[Perth Spirit]] played at Perth Oval during the 2007 [[Australian Rugby Championship]].{{cite news | url=http://www.theaustralian.com.au/rugby-wa-launches-perth-spirit/story-e6frf33c-1111113197159 | title=Rugby WA launches Perth Spirit | work=The Australian | date=21 March 2007 | accessdate=8 July 2007|archiveurl= https://www.webcitation.org/62YUiol0k |archivedate=20 October 2011}} Since 2010 the [[Western Force]] have called Perth Oval home and together with co-tenants [[Perth Glory]], helped instigate the stadium's most recent re-development. {| class="wikitable" |- style="background:#bdb76b;" ! Game !! Date !! Team !! Result !! Team !! Attendance !! Part of |- |1 || 17 September 2017 || align=right|{{ru-rt|AUS}} || align=center|[[2016 Rugby Championship#Round 4|36–20]] || {{ru|ARG}} || 20,826 || [[2016 Rugby Championship]] |- |2 || 9 September 2017 || align=right|{{ru-rt|AUS}} || align=center|[[2017 Rugby Championship#Round 3|23–23]] || {{ru|RSA}} || 17,528 || [[2017 Rugby Championship]] |} ===Rugby league=== Rugby league has been an annual fixture at nib stadium since 2009, with [[South Sydney Rabbitohs]] hosting a home game once a season with the [[Manly-Warringah Sea Eagles]] joining them from 2016 onwards. The biggest crowds have occurred in games involving the [[New Zealand Warriors]]. It was announced in January 2016 that the stadium would host Perth's first rugby league test match between the [[Australian Kangaroos]] and the [[New Zealand national rugby league team|New Zealand Kiwis]] on 15 October 2016.[http://www.nrl.com/perth-to-host-october-test-match/tabid/10874/newsid/91450/default.aspx Perth to host October test match] National Rugby League It was also selected as a venue for the [[2017 Rugby League World Cup]]. List of rugby league test matches played at the Perth Oval.{{cite web|url=http://www.rugbyleagueproject.org/venues/perth-oval/summary.html|title=Perth Oval - Current Name: nib Stadium - Rugby League Project|first=Shawn Dollin and Andrew|last=Ferguson|work=rugbyleagueproject.org|accessdate=15 October 2016}} {| class="wikitable" |- style="background:#bdb76b;" ! Game !! Date !! Team !! Result !! Team !! Attendance !! Part of |- |1 || 15 October 2016 || align=right|{{rl-rt|AUS}} || align=center|[[2016 Rugby League Four Nations#Australia vs New Zealand|26–6]] || {{rl|NZL}} || 20,283 || [[2016 Rugby League Four Nations|2016 Four Nations]] |- |2 || 12 November 2017 || align=right|{{rl-rt|ENG}} || align=center|[[2017 Rugby League World Cup Group A#England v France|36–6]] || {{rl|FRA}} || 14,744 || [[2017 Rugby League World Cup Group A|2017 World Cup Group A]] |- |3 || 12 November 2017 || align=right|{{rl-rt|Wales}} || align=center|[[2017 Rugby League World Cup Group C#Wales v Ireland|6–34]] || {{rl|Ireland}} || 14,744 || [[2017 Rugby League World Cup Group C|2017 World Cup Group C]] |} The first game played at the venue was in the [[1997 Super League (Australia) season|1997 Super League season]]. The Perth-based [[Western Reds]] moved their round 4 game against the [[Canterbury Bulldogs]] to the oval due to the unavailability of their usual home ground, the [[WACA Ground|WACA]]. On that occasion the Reds won 36–6 in what was the venue's smallest rugby league attendance (until 2017) of 7,135.{{cite web|url=http://www.rugbyleagueproject.org/seasons/super-league-1997/round-4/western-reds-vs-canterbury/summary.html|title=Super League 1997 - Round 4 - Rugby League Project|first=Shawn Dollin and Andrew|last=Ferguson|work=rugbyleagueproject.org|accessdate=15 October 2016}} ====NRL games==== {| class="wikitable" |- style="background:#bdb76b;" ! [[South Sydney Rabbitohs]] || 11,433 || [[2017 NRL season]] |- |14 || 1 July 2017 || {{leagueicon|Manly|16}} [[Manly-Warringah Sea Eagles]] || align=center|[[2017 NRL season|26–22]] || {{leagueicon|New Zealand|16}} [[New Zealand Warriors]] || 6,258 || [[2017 NRL season]] |} ===Record attendances=== The record crowd for the ground is 32,000 for the [[Ed Sheeran]] concert on 2 December 2015, overtaking the previous record of 31,997http://www.nibstadium.com.au/news/foo-fighters-breaks-nib-stadium-attendance-figures for the last Foo Fighters concert in 2015. The record sport attendance is 27,473, for an [[Interstate matches in Australian rules football|interstate]] Australian football match between [[Western Australia Australian rules football team|Western Australia]] and [[Victoria Australian rules football team|Victoria]] on 6 July 1929 – which was at the time the record football crowd in Western Australian history.{{cite news|newspaper=The West Australian|publication-place=Perth, WA|title=Football carnival|page=15|date=16 August 1937}} The highest crowd for a club match was 26,760 for the 31 May 1969 [[Local derby#Australia|derby]] Australian football match between [[East Perth Football Club|East Perth]] and [[West Perth Football Club|West Perth]].{{citation needed|date=July 2015}} The record football crowd for a match at the ground is 19,495, for a [[2018 FIFA World Cup qualification (AFC)|2018 FIFA World Cup qualifier]] between the [[Australia national soccer team|Socceroos]] and [[Bangladesh national football team|Bangladesh]], bettering the previous record of 18,067 in the 1998–99 [[National Soccer League (Australia)|NSL]] season game between [[Perth Glory FC|Perth Glory]] and [[South Melbourne FC]]. The record rugby union crowd at the venue prior to the 2012-13 redevelopment is an estimated 22,000 in a [[2011 Super Rugby season#Round 11|Super Rugby 2011 Season]] game between the [[Western Force]] and [[Crusaders (rugby)|Crusaders]] on 30 April 2011. The record sports crowd at the venue since the 2012-13 redevelopment is 20,727 in a [[2015 NRL season results#Round 13|2015 NRL season]] game between the [[South Sydney Rabbitohs]] and [[New Zealand Warriors]] on 6 June 2015. ==Music== [[File:RogerWatersPerthAustralia2007.jpg|right|thumb|225px|Roger Waters performing on his Dark Side Of The Moon Live tour in 2007]] nib Stadium has been the venue of major music concerts, including: {| class="wikitable" !colspan=3|Concerts |- ! {{no footnotes|date=November 2015}} {{orphan|date=June 2015}}
{{Infobox person |name=Pros Vs. Heroes |image= Pros-Vs.-Heroes-Logo - Copy.png |caption= '''Created by:''' [[Darian Barnes]]
'''Founded:''' 2014
'''Country of Origin:''' [[United States]]
'''Games Played:''' 5
'''Official Website:''' http://www.prosvsheroes.us/
'''Youtube Channel:''' https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCN9rZTQz1SmvADOWFuegJkg
'''Twitter Page:''' https://twitter.com/prosvsheroes }}
'''Pros Vs. Heroes''' is a corporation created by former [[NFL]] Player [[Darian Barnes]]. Pros Vs. Heroes is a fundraising platform created to raise money and awareness for charities.
== About == The game has former [[NFL]], current [[NFL]], [[American Football League|AFL]], [[Legends Football League]] and other professional athletes travel around the country to play in flag football games against police officers, fire fighters, armed forces and EMT personnel. The corporation was created in 2014 and is now expanding to different areas around the [[United States]]. Barnes created this organization to raise money and give back to communities. Since its first game in June 2014, the program has raised a large amount{{clarify|date=November 2015}} of profits in the five games.
In the last year, five games have been played in the Pros Vs. Heroes series. The first and second game was played at Toms River North, [[New Jersey]] against the Toms River Force and South River Brave. The third game was played in [[Arizona]] against the Chandler Police Officers and Fire Department at WestWood High School. Recently, the last two games were played at [[Seaside Heights]], [[New Jersey]] during the Jersey Shore Festival where the Pros took on Homeland Security and the Toms River Police Department. Currently, the Pros record stands at 4-1.

{{Bus icon|12px|Local Transit}} [[TriMet|SW 18th & Morrison]]: [[TriMet|18]], [[TriMet|63]] |}} '''Providence Park''' (formerly '''Jeld-Wen Field'''; '''PGE Park'''; '''Civic Stadium'''; originally '''Multnomah Stadium'''; and from 1893 until the stadium was built, '''Multnomah Field''') is an outdoor sports venue in the [[Pacific Northwest|northwest]] [[United States]], located in the [[Goose Hollow, Portland, Oregon|Goose Hollow]] neighborhood of [[Portland, Oregon]]. It has existed in rudimentary form since 1893, and as a complete stadium since 1926. The [[Major League Soccer|MLS]] [[Portland Timbers]] and [[National Women's Soccer League|NWSL]] [[Portland Thorns FC]] [[soccer]] teams use the facility as their home [[pitch (sports field)|pitch]], as do the [[Premier Development League|PDL]]'s [[Portland Timbers U23s|Timbers U23s]]. The [[NCAA Division I]] [[Football Championship Subdivision|FCS]] [[Portland State Vikings football]] team uses the park during the [[Big Sky Conference|Big Sky]] season. The stadium has been host to several major sporting events including [[Soccer Bowl '77]], the [[1999 FIFA Women's World Cup|1999]] and [[2003 FIFA Women's World Cup]]s, the 2009 [[Triple-A All-Star Game]], the [[2013 CONCACAF Gold Cup]], the [[2014 MLS All-Star Game]] and the [[2015 National Women's Soccer League season#Championship|2015 NWSL Championship Game]]. The stadium capacity will be expanded with 4,000 new seats within the next years.http://stadiumdb.com/news/2017/04/new_design_five_tiers_for_portland Originally, the park was owned by the [[Multnomah Athletic Club]] and used by their amateur sports teams. In the 1950s, the [[Pacific Coast League|PCL]] [[Portland Beavers]] [[baseball]] team moved out of [[Vaughn Street Park]] into what was then known as "Multnomah Stadium." In 1966, the city purchased the stadium and renamed it "Civic Stadium." It was renovated in 2001 to accommodate the Beavers, who had not played at the park since the early 1990s. The naming rights of the stadium were purchased by [[Portland General Electric]] and it was renamed "PGE Park." In 2010, the park underwent renovations again, this time so it could accommodate the Portland Timbers MLS franchise and a year later the rights to the stadiums name were sold, this time to [[Jeld-Wen]]. In 2014, the name was changed again to "Providence Park" after [[Providence Health & Services]] bought the naming rights.{{cite news|url=http://www.oregonlive.com/timbers/index.ssf/2014/02/portland_timbers_make_an_annou.html|title=Portland Timbers to rename their stadium Providence Park|date=February 10, 2014|accessdate=February 10, 2014|newspaper=The Oregonian|last=Goldberg|first=Jamie}} The stadium sits on a rectangular block bounded by Southwest Morrison Street, Southwest 18th Avenue, the Multnomah Athletic Club building and Southwest Salmon Street, and Southwest 20th Avenue.{{cite news|title=Vikings Play At Jeld-Wen Field In 2011|url=http://goviks.com/news/2011/3/14/FB_0314112948.aspx}}{{cite news|title=PGE Park renamed Jeld-Wen Field|url=http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/42078697}} ==Description== Providence Park is an outdoor stadium which houses the [[Major League Soccer|MLS]] [[Portland Timbers]], [[National Women's Soccer League|NWSL]] [[Portland Thorns FC|Portland Thorns]], and [[Portland State Vikings football|Portland State University Vikings]] football. The stadium underwent a $31 million renovation in late 2010 and early 2011.{{cite web |url=http://www.portlandtimbers.com/stadium-renovation |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2011-03-17 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110414041534/http://www.portlandtimbers.com/stadium-renovation |archivedate=April 14, 2011 |df=mdy-all }} The stadium is owned by the City of Portland, and is managed by Peregrine Sports, LLC, the entity that owns the Timbers and Thorns. Prior to the 2011 MLS season, the stadium was renamed Jeld-Wen Field from PGE Park, in a partnership with [[Klamath Falls, Oregon]] based company Jeld-Wen. Jeld-Wen is a manufacturer of windows and doors, leading to the stadium's nickname, "The House of Pane." In 2014, the stadium was renamed Providence Park after a partnership with [[Providence Health & Services]] was announced. The [[Multnomah Athletic Club]], an [[sports club|athletic club]] in downtown Portland, stands next door; the windows of the north side of the club's building overlook the field. The [[Interstate 405 (Oregon)|Interstate 405]] freeway in Portland is also known locally as the Stadium Freeway and travels near the stadium. In addition, the [[Providence Park (MAX station)|Providence Park]] [[MAX Light Rail]] station is across the street. The property slopes significantly downhill from the south end to the north end, with the result that the playing surface sits well below street level, the [[elevation]] at street level is approximately {{convert|110|ft|round=5}} above [[sea level]]. ==Tenants== The stadium is currently home to the [[Portland Timbers]] of [[Major League Soccer|MLS]], [[Portland Thorns FC]] of [[National Women's Soccer League|NWSL]], and is also used for several [[Portland State Vikings football|Portland State University Vikings]] [[American football|football]] home games each season. ===Former tenants=== The [[Portland Beavers]] [[minor league baseball]] team of the [[Pacific Coast League]] (PCL) had played some games at Multnomah Field during 1905 when their [[Vaughn Street Park]] was temporarily reconfigured to host a track and field event. They moved into Multnomah Stadium in 1956 after over a half century at Vaughn Street, a wooden [[Baseball park|ballpark]] which was soon demolished. The sod from the baseball field at Vaughn Street was transferred to the new venue; Civic Stadium installed [[artificial turf]] in 1969. [[File:Multnomah Stadium postcard.jpg|175px|left|thumb|Before the city purchased the stadium, it was owned by the [[Multnomah Athletic Club]]]] From 1973 to 1977 the [[independent baseball league|independent]] [[Portland Mavericks]] of the [[Northwest League]] played their home games at the stadium. Actor [[Kurt Russell]] was an [[infielder]] for the Mavericks.{{cite web|title=Kurt Russell Minor League Statistics & History|url=https://www.baseball-reference.com/minors/player.cgi?id=russel001kur|work=Baseball-Reference.com|accessdate=13 February 2014}} The Beavers returned to Portland in 1978 until 1993 when they were moved out of the city again. The [[Class A (baseball)|Class A]] [[Portland Rockies]] were established in 1995 and played at the park until 2000 when they were moved and renamed the [[Tri-City Dust Devils]]. In 2001, the [[Albuquerque Dukes]] were moved to Portland and renamed the "Beavers" marking the third time the franchise would occupy the park for their home games. As a baseball venue, the stadium had an unorthodox south-southeast alignment, with home plate in the northwest corner (20th and Morrison) of the property. After it was announced that [[Major League Soccer]] was moving a franchise to Providence Park (then known as PGE Park) the Beavers baseball team had to start looking for a [[Portland Beavers Ballpark|new stadium]]. However, the plan never came to fruition and team owner [[Merritt Paulson]] put the Beavers up for sale. The club's [[Major League Baseball|major-league]] parent, the [[San Diego Padres]], purchased the team, which moved to [[Tucson, Arizona]] as the [[Tucson Padres]]. The team played its final game at the stadium on September 6, 2010.{{cite news|title=Portland Beavers Moving to Tucson|url=http://ballparkdigest.com/201010153186/minor-league-baseball/features/bevos-to-tucson-for-2011}}{{cite news|url=http://blog.oregonlive.com/portlandcityhall/2009/05/beavers_must_move_out_of_pge_p.html|title=Beavers Must Move Out of PGE Park, League Says|last=Larabee|first=Mark|date=May 29, 2009|newspaper=[[The Oregonian]]|accessdate=2009-09-13}} The stadium hosted the [[United States Football League|USFL]]'s [[Portland Breakers]], as well as the [[Portland Storm]] and [[Portland Thunder]] of the [[World Football League|WFL]]. Soccer has been hosted at Providence Park since the [[Portland Timbers (1975–1982)|original Portland Timbers]] were founded in the original [[North American Soccer League (1968–1984)|North American Soccer League]] in 1975. Various iterations of the team have called the stadium home, including the [[Portland Timbers (1985–1990)|1980s version]] in the [[Western Soccer Alliance]] and the [[Portland Timbers (2001–2010)|2000s version]] in the [[USL First Division]] before the MLS club was formed. ==History== [[File:Multnomah Stadium, 1940s.jpg|thumb|Providence Park (then known as Multnomah Civic Stadium) photographed in 1941]] Since 1893, the site had been home to Multnomah Field, which consisted of sports fields with various [[grandstand]]s.{{cite web|url=http://ohs.org/education/oregonhistory/historical_records/dspDocument.cfm?doc_ID=0009B37C-450F-1E94-891B80B0527200A7 |title=Civic Stadium |publisher=Oregon Historical Society |accessdate=April 27, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060104033306/http://ohs.org/education/oregonhistory/historical_records/dspDocument.cfm?doc_ID=0009B37C-450F-1E94-891B80B0527200A7 |archivedate=January 4, 2006 }}{{cite web | url=http://www.oregonencyclopedia.org/articles/multnomah_stadium_civic_stadium_pge_park_jeld_wen_field_/ | title=Multnomah Stadium | website=www.oregonencyclopedia.org | access-date=January 16, 2016}} The stadium was built in 1926 for $502,000, by what is now known as Multnomah Athletic Club, who named it '''Multnomah Civic Stadium'''.{{cite web| url= http://www.oregonlive.com/timbers/index.ssf/2014/02/issues_and_answers_no_matter_w.html | title= Issues and Answers: No matter what the stadium is called, Providence Park is a place where memories are made | date= February 11, 2014 | first= Jason |last= Quick| publisher= The Oregonian | quote= It was built in 1926 by what is now the Multnomah Athletic Club for $502,000 and called Multnomah Civic Stadium. In 1966, it was sold to the city of Portland for $2.1 million, and became known as Civic Stadium. In 2001, it became PGE Park and in 2011 Jeld-Wen Field. |accessdate= 2014-08-07}} [[File:Multnomah Stadium, 1940.JPG|thumb|left|The stadium in 1940]] The site was used for college football (including seven [[Civil War (college football game)|Civil War games]] between the [[Oregon Ducks football|University of Oregon]] and [[Oregon State Beavers football|Oregon State University]]), cricket matches and [[greyhound racing]]. Well into the 1960s, most significant football games hosted by Oregon and Oregon State were held at this site because of its capacity. Oregon played in [[Oregon Ducks football venues#Multnomah Field (1894–1925) / Multnomah Stadium (1926–1970)|107 games]] at Multnomah/Civic Stadium between 1894 and 1970. The [[Washington Huskies football|University of Washington]] played all its road games against Oregon and Oregon State at Multnomah Field/Multnomah Stadium until 1966 (OSU) and 1967 (Oregon). The site also hosted the [[Portland Rose Festival]] coronation and a Fourth of July appearance by President [[Warren G. Harding]]. In the 1950s, the [[Portland Beavers]] moved to the stadium after their original field, [[Vaughn Street Park]], was condemned. In 1966, the Multnomah Athletic Club sold the stadium for $2.1 million to the city of Portland, which renamed it '''Civic Stadium'''.{{cite press release |title=Timbers rename home stadium JELD-WEN Field |url=http://www.portlandtimbers.com/news/2011/03/timbers-rename-home-stadium-jeld-wen-field |publisher=Portland Timbers |date=March 14, 2011 |accessdate=April 27, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110318054827/http://www.portlandtimbers.com/news/2011/03/timbers-rename-home-stadium-jeld-wen-field |archivedate=March 18, 2011 |df=mdy-all }} ===Renovations=== A $38.5 million renovation took place in 2001, upgrading the seating and concourse area, and adding new [[Luxury box|luxury suites]] and club seats. The renovation improved the structural soundness of the facility, and introduced a new sound system. The renovation also includes some [[Retro style|retro-features]], such as a manually operated [[Scoreboard#Baseball|baseball scoreboard]]. At that point, [[Portland General Electric|PGE]] bought the naming rights and it became '''PGE Park'''. [[File:Jeldwenfield2011.png|thumb|right|Panoramic view of the renovated eastern stands and northwest luxury boxes, during a Timbers game]] [[File:Providence Park main entrance - Portland, Oregon.JPG|thumb|Main entrance with stadium as Providence Park]] In July 2009, after attempts to both find a new home for an MLS franchise and identify a [[Portland Beavers Ballpark|site for a new home for the Portland Beavers]], the [[Government of Portland, Oregon|Portland City Council]] approved a $31 million renovation to make PGE Park ready for the [[2011 Major League Soccer season]], by reconfiguring the stadium primarily for soccer and football.{{Cite news |url =http://www.oregonlive.com/portland/index.ssf/2009/06/major_league_soccer_plan_still.html|title=Major League Soccer plan still alive as Portland council endorses latest plan|date=June 24, 2009|access-date=June 25, 2009|last=Larabee|first=Mark|work=[[The Oregonian]]}}{{cite news|last=Haberman|first=Margaret|title=$31 million PGE Park renovation passes 4–1|date=July 23, 2009|newspaper=[[The Oregonian]]|url=http://www.oregonlive.com/portland/index.ssf/2009/07/31_million_pge_park_renovation.html|access-date=April 18, 2011}} The decision led to the departure of the Beavers. [[File:Providence Park.jpg|thumb|left|The stadium in 2016]] The renovation was performed by [[Turner Construction]], who served as the general contractor and also performed the 2001 renovation, and [[Ellerbe Becket]] as the primary architect. A presentation to the Portland Design Commission indicated that 5,000 seats would be added, bringing capacity to about 22,000, but with only about 18,000 available for use on a regular basis.{{cite news|last=Jug|first=Helen|title=Vision for PGE Park: A place that says 'soccer'|date=August 5, 2009|newspaper=[[The Oregonian]]|url=http://blog.oregonlive.com/portlandbeavers/2009/08/renovated_pge_park_will_showca.html|access-date=April 18, 2011|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110311034002/http://blog.oregonlive.com/portlandbeavers/2009/08/renovated_pge_park_will_showca.html|archive-date=March 11, 2011|dead-url=yes|df=mdy-all}} The renovation met Major League Soccer standards, introduced a new playing surface, which shifted west and north, and added space on the east and south sides, with new seating areas and new amenities. The Lighthouse Impact 16 main video screen was designed by Anthony James Partners and features over 74 square meters of LED video. A Lighthouse B10 pitchside display runs the length of the east side and portions of the north and south ends and is over 152 meters long.{{cite news|title=Lighthouse and TS Sports Make an Impact with LED Video at Portland's Jeld Wen Field|url=http://www.lighthouse-tech.com/PressReleasesDetail.aspx?id=d1b2f0c0-c2aa-483d-98b7-83a72fb6a75e&c=2011|date=May 17, 2011|access-date=August 21, 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110909174049/http://www.lighthouse-tech.com/PressReleasesDetail.aspx?id=d1b2f0c0-c2aa-483d-98b7-83a72fb6a75e&c=2011|archivedate=September 9, 2011|df=mdy-all}} As the project was nearing completion, it was revealed to be $5 million over budget, making the total cost of the renovation $36 million.{{cite web|last=Neves|first=Randy|title=PGE Park project $5 million over budget|url=http://www.kgw.com/news/local/Cost-overruns-at-PGE-no-problem-say-Timbers-and-City-Commissioner-117284533.html|publisher=KGW|access-date=July 2, 2011|date=March 3, 2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120117094617/http://www.kgw.com/news/local/Cost-overruns-at-PGE-no-problem-say-Timbers-and-City-Commissioner-117284533.html|archivedate=January 17, 2012|df=mdy-all}} The agreement between the city and Portland Timbers owner Merritt Paulson meant that Paulson was responsible for any cost overruns larger than $1 million. The newly renovated stadium made its début on April 14, 2011, when Major League Soccer's Timbers defeated the [[Chicago Fire Soccer Club|Chicago Fire]], 4–2.{{cite news|title=PGE Park would have similar capacity under soccer remodel, designers say|url=http://www.oregonlive.com/portland/index.ssf/2009/09/pge_park_would_have_similar_ca.html|date=September 22, 2009|newspaper=The Oregonian|access-date=April 18, 2011}} The announced attendance at Timbers games in 2011 was 18,627, a sell-out. A few thousand seats were added for two games late in the 2011 season. About 2,000 seats were opened up for the 2012 season, bringing capacity up to 20,438. Following the 2012 season in which the Timbers' average attendance was 20,438, during the 2012–13 off-season the Timbers widened the pitch for the 2013 season, adding two yards on each side to achieve a width of {{convert|74|yd|m}}.{{cite news |url= http://www.oregonlive.com/timbers/index.ssf/2012/08/portland_timbers_to_widen_fiel.html|title=Portland Timbers to widen field for 2013 season|accessdate=January 7, 2013|first=Geoffrey C.|last=Arnold|date=August 28, 2012}} The team widened the pitch by another yard in 2014, for a total pitch size of {{convert|110|x|75|yd|m}}. In April 2017, the Portland Timbers unveiled a [[United States dollar|US$]]50 million renovation plan which would add roughly 4,000 new seats to the eastern side of the stadium.{{Cite web | author=Timbers.com Staff | date=April 26, 2017 | title=A soccer cathedral grows: Providence Park to add approximately 4,000 new seats in modern expansion | Portland Timbers | url=http://www.timbers.com/post/2017/04/26/soccer-cathedral-grows-providence-park-add-approximately-4000-new-seats-modern | website=Timbers.com | access-date=April 29, 2017}} Timbers' President of Business Mike Golub stated that "We felt it was imperative to see how we could transform the stadium and add capacity to both meet the demand that we have for tickets and also position the club to be viable and competitive for years to come", referencing the Timbers' current season ticket waitlist of approximately 13,000. The Timbers report that the renovation will come at no cost to the City of Portland and will bring the stadium capacity to roughly 25,000. The club partnered with Portland-based Allied Works Architecture to design the expansion, and aims to begin construction in the 2017 or 2018 off-season with the goal of having the renovated stadium ready for the 2019 or 2020 MLS season.{{cite news |url= http://www.oregonlive.com/timbers/index.ssf/2017/04/portland_timbers_moving_forwar.html|title=Portland Timbers unveil $50 million stadium expansion plan for Providence Park|access-date=April 27, 2017|first=Jaime|last=Goldberg|date=April 26, 2017}} ==Events== ===Soccer=== [[File:Portland Timbers FC.jpg|thumb|right|Soccer game in the USL years, viewing the old configuration of the eastern wall]] On August 28, 1977, the stadium was site of the [[North American Soccer League (1968–1984)|North American Soccer League]] [[Soccer Bowl '77]] between the [[New York Cosmos (1971–1985)|New York Cosmos]] and the [[Seattle Sounders (NASL)|Seattle Sounders]], the last official game of the legendary [[Pelé]]. The Cosmos won the championship. On September 7, 1997 the stadium hosted a World Cup soccer qualifying match between the [[United States men's national soccer team|United States men's national team]] and [[Costa Rica national football team|Costa Rica]]. A raucous capacity crowd of 27,396 saw the U.S. squad win, 1–0, on a goal by [[Tab Ramos]] in the 79th minute. The stadium was the site of four group matches in the [[1999 FIFA Women's World Cup|1999 Women's World Cup]]. The stadium also hosted two group matches, two quarterfinals, and both semifinals in the [[2003 FIFA Women's World Cup|2003 Women's World Cup]]. On July 1, 2009, the venue hosted the third-round match of the [[Lamar Hunt U.S. Open Cup]] between the [[Portland Timbers (2001–10)|Portland Timbers]] and their rivals the [[Seattle Sounders FC]]. Providence Park hosted the [[2014 MLS All-Star Game]].{{cite news|url=http://www.oregonlive.com/timbers/index.ssf/2013/07/portland_to_host_2014_mls_all-.html|title=Portland to host 2014 MLS All-Star Game|last=Arnold|first=Geoffrey C.|newspaper=The Oregonian|accessdate=July 11, 2013|date=July 11, 2013}}{{cite web|title=Portland to host 2014 All Star Game|publisher=StadiaDirectory.com|url=http://www.stadiadirectory.com/portland-to-host-2014-all-star-game/|accessdate=2013-07-11|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130719164754/http://www.stadiadirectory.com/portland-to-host-2014-all-star-game/|archivedate=July 19, 2013|df=mdy-all}} ====1999 FIFA Women's World Cup matches==== ''Stadium known as '''Civic Stadium''''' {{clear}} {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:left; width:60%;" style="text-align:center" |- !Date !Time ([[Pacific Time Zone|PDT]]) !Team #1 !Result !Team #2 !Group !Attendance |- |rowspan=2|June 23||18.00||align=left|{{fbw|JPN}}||0–5||align=left|{{fbw|RUS}}||Group C||rowspan=2|17,668 |- |20.30||align=left|{{fbw|CHN}}||7–0||align=left|{{fbw|GHA}}||Group D |- |rowspan=2|{{spaces|5}}June 24{{spaces|5}}||18.00||align=left|{{fbw|PRK}}||3–1||align=left|{{fbw|DEN}}||Group A||rowspan=2|20,129 |- |20.30||align=left|{{fbw|GER}}||6–0||align=left|{{fbw|MEX}}||Group B |} ====2003 FIFA Women's World Cup matches==== ''Stadium known as '''PGE Park''''' {{clear}} {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:left; width:60%;" style="text-align:center" |- !Date !Time ([[Pacific Time Zone|PDT]]) !Team #1 !Result !Team #2 !Round !Attendance |- |rowspan=2|September 26||17.15||align=left|{{fbw|GHA}}||2–1||align=left|{{fbw|AUS}}||rowspan=2|[[2003 FIFA Women's World Cup#Group D|Group D]]||rowspan=2|19,132 |- |20.00||align=left|{{fbw|CHN}}||1–0||align=left|{{fbw|RUS}} |- |rowspan=2|October 2||19.30||align=left|{{fbw|GER}}||7–1||align=left|{{fbw|RUS}}||rowspan=2|[[2003 FIFA Women's World Cup#Quarterfinals|Quarter
finals]]||rowspan=2|20,021 |- |22.30||align=left|{{fbw|CHN}}||0–1||align=left|{{fbw|CAN}} |- |rowspan=2|October 5||19.30||align=left|{{fbw|USA}}||0–3||align=left|{{fbw|GER}}||rowspan=2|[[2003 FIFA Women's World Cup#Semifinals|Semi
finals]]||rowspan=2|27,623 |- |22.30||align=left|{{fbw|SWE}}||2–1||align=left|{{fbw|CAN}} |} ====2013 CONCACAF Gold Cup matches==== ''Stadium known as '''Jeld-Wen Field''''' {{clear}} {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:left; width:60%;" style="text-align:center" |- !Date !Time ([[Pacific Time Zone|PDT]]) !Team #1 !Result !Team #2 !Group !Attendance |- |rowspan=2|{{spaces|6}}July 9{{spaces|6}}||20.30||align=left|{{fb|CRC}}||3–0||align=left|{{fb|CUB}}||rowspan=2|[[2013 CONCACAF Gold Cup Group C|Group C]]||rowspan=2|18,724 |- |23.00||align=left|{{fb|BLZ}}||1–6||align=left|{{fb|USA}} |} ===Baseball=== [[File:PGEPark.jpg|thumb|right|Facing south towards the Multnomah Athletic Club, during a baseball game in 2008]] During the 1970s, the Jantzen swim wear company had a 3D model of the Jantzen girl hovering overby cable over the left field wall in its baseball configuration. The Jantzen girl was in play because it was below the top of the wall and it was hit a couple of times over the years.{{cite web|title=OSU in Portland|publisher=Kyle Odegard|url=http://kyleodegard.mvourtown.com/2008/03/05/osu-in-portland/|accessdate=2009-06-23}}{{dead link|date=April 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}{{cite book|title=The Portland Beavers|publisher=Arcadia Publishing, page 82|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=4386AUmRw7IC&pg=PA82&lpg=PA82&dq=jantzen+portland+civic+stadium|accessdate=2009-06-23|isbn=978-0-7385-3266-0|date=August 2004}} On May 27, 1991, the stadium received national attention when [[Vancouver Canadians]] outfielder [[Rodney McCray (baseball)|Rodney McCray]], while attempting to catch a fly ball, crashed through a wooden advertisement behind the [[warning track]] in right-center field; a real-life version of an incident in the fictional book and film, ''[[The Natural]]''. While McCray failed to make the out, he only suffered scrapes and bruises and remained in the game. Highlight reels of that play ran for weeks on cable channels such as [[CNN]] and [[ESPN]]. On August 12, 2006, the Beavers commemorated the event with a Rodney McCray Bobblehead Night, passing out [[bobblehead]]s of McCray to fans and renaming right-center field "McCray Alley".{{cite news|last=Bachman|first=Rachel|title=An effort at de-fence worth remembering|url=http://www.oregonlive.com/sports/oregonian/index.ssf?/base/sports/1155353118120820.xml&coll=7|work=[[The Oregonian]]|date=August 12, 2006|accessdate=2007-01-21}} On July 15, 2009, the stadium hosted the [[Triple-A All-Star Game]], with the [[International League]] stars defeating the Pacific Coast league, 6–5. The game was attended by 16,637 fans, the largest crowd for a Triple-A All-Star game since 1991, and the third largest at the time.{{Cite web|url=http://www.triple-abaseball.com/ASGSummaries5.jsp|title=Triple-A All-Star Game Results (2008–2012)|publisher=Triple-A Baseball|accessdate=July 7, 2017}} Portland's [[Chad Huffman]] won the [[Triple-A Home Run Derby|Home Run Derby]].{{cite book |section=Triple-A All-Star Home Run Derby Winners |title=2017 Pacific Coast League Sketch & Record Book |publisher=Pacific Coast League |year=2017 |page=162}} ===College Football=== [[File:Multnomah Stadium football game.jpg|thumb|180px|A night football game at Providence Park (then known as Multnomah Stadium)]] On October 27, 2007, the stadium hosted the highest-scoring game in modern [[NCAA]] [[American football|football]] history, when the [[Weber State Wildcats football|Weber State University Wildcats]] [[2007 Weber State vs. Portland State football game|defeated the PSU Vikings, 73–68]], a combined point total of 141 points. This point total eclipsed the previous NCAA record of 136 points, set in a 1968 [[NCAA Division III|Division III]] game, and the previous [[NCAA Division I|Division I]] record of 133 points, set in 2004.{{cite news|url=http://www.sltrib.com/collegesports/ci_7303564 |title=Weber State football: Wildcats earn record-setting win |agency=Associated Press |date=2007-10-28 |accessdate=2007-10-29 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080206060914/http://www.sltrib.com/collegesports/ci_7303564 |archivedate=February 6, 2008 }} While this record lasted only two weeks, and has been surpassed three times in all, it remains the highest-scoring game involving [[NCAA Division I]] teams. ===Concerts=== On September 2, 1957, [[Elvis Presley]] performed one of the first outdoor stadium rock concerts in music history (Presley held the first ever in Vancouver, BC, Canada just a few days earlier at Empire Stadium) there on his four-day tour of the Pacific Northwest. The concert created mass hysteria, and an estimated 14,000 people attended the concert.{{cite web|url=http://www.elvispresleymusic.com.au/pictures/1957_september_2_portland.html|title=Elvis Presley: Multnomah Civic Stadium Portland, OR : September 2, 1957|publisher=|access-date=January 16, 2016}}{{cite web|url=http://www.scottymoore.net/portland57.html|title=Scotty Moore – Multnomah Civic Stadium – Portland, OR|publisher=|access-date=January 16, 2016}} In a November 8, 2013 interview with the Portland Business Journal, Portland Timbers owner Merritt Paulson expressed his desire to host summer concerts at the stadium. {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:center;" |- ! width=12% style="text-align:center;| Date ! width=10% style="text-align:center;| Artist ! width=10% style="text-align:center;| Opening act(s) ! width=16% style="text-align:center;| Tour / Concert name ! width=10% style="text-align:center;| Attendance ! width=10% style="text-align:center;| Revenue ! width=20% style="text-align:center;| Notes |- | August 14, 1987 || [[David Bowie]] || [[Duran Duran]] || [[Glass Spider Tour]] || — || — || |- | September 15, 1995 || [[Van Halen]] || — || [[The Balance "Ambulance" Tour]] || — || — || |} ===In popular culture=== In 2010, PGE Park was a filming location of Season 2 of the television series ''[[Leverage (TV series)|Leverage]]''. The episode depicts a fictional Massachusetts (where the series was set) minor league team also known as the Beavers.{{cite web|url=http://www.oregonlive.com/movies/index.ssf/2009/07/leverage_turns_portland_into_b.html|title='Leverage' turns Portland into 'Beantown West'|work=OregonLive.com|access-date=January 16, 2016}} ===Feral cat colony=== The field has been home to a [[feral cat]] colony since approximately 1985, which may have been at the park before the current stadium opened in 1926. There are an estimated 12–19 cats in the colony, referred to as "living rat traps".{{cite news|url=http://www.oregonlive.com/pbeavers/index.ssf/2009/06/portland_beavers_ken_puckett_n.html|title=Portland Beavers' Ken Puckett nearing milestone (1,000 consecutive events) for durability|last=Hunt|first=John|date=June 12, 2009|newspaper=[[The Oregonian]]|accessdate=April 11, 2011}} After a construction worker killed a feral cat in 2000, the park enlisted the [[Feral Cat Coalition of Oregon]] to assist the animals during construction efforts and to run a [[trap-neuter-return]] program. The cats are discussed in [[Chuck Palahniuk]]'s travelogue of Portland, ''[[Fugitives and Refugees]]''.{{cite news|url=http://www.oregonlive.com/pets/index.ssf/2011/04/pet_talk_jeld-wen_field_takes.html|title=Jeld-Wen Field crews take care of feral cat colony while getting ready for the Portland Timbers|last=Balas|first=Monique|date=April 11, 2011|newspaper=[[The Oregonian]]|accessdate=April 11, 2011}}{{cite book|last=Palahniuk|first=Chuck|title=Fugitives and Refugees: A Walk in Portland, Oregon|year=2003|publisher=Crown Journeys|location=New York|isbn=1-4000-4783-8|pages=153–155}} ==Gallery== File:Multnomah Stadium – 1930.jpg|The park photographed from the street in 1930 File:Multnomah Stadium, 1956.jpeg|An aerial view of the park in 1956 File:Civic Stadium, 1969.JPG|An aerial view of the park in 1969 File:Civic Stadium, 1974.JPG|An aerial view of the park in 1974 File:Multnomah Stadium, 1974 (2).JPG|The park photographed towards the north end in 1974 File:PGE Park in 2008, from elevated position.jpg|The east entrance to the park in 2008 File:Man watching {{refimprove|date=April 2017}} {{Infobox football club | clubname = Al-Riffa| image = [[Image:Riffa SC (logo).png|180px|Logo]]| fullname = Al-Riffa Sports Club| nickname = Their Excellencies, The Lions| founded = {{Start date and age|1953}}| ground = [[Bahrain National Stadium]]
Riffa, Bahrain| Twitter = @Riffa_Club| Instagram = @RiffaSportsClub| capacity = 23,000| chairman = Sh. Abdulla bin Khalid Al-Khalifa| manager = Ali Ashour| mediator = Khaled Alsuwaidi| league = [[Nasser Bin Hamad League]] | season = [[2014–15 Bahrain First Division League|2017–18]] | position = 7th | }} '''Al-Riffa Sports Club''' ({{lang-ar|نادي الرفاع الرياضي}}) is a [[Bahrain]]i [[football (soccer)|football]] club based in [[Riffa]], playing in the top division of Bahraini football league. The club was founded in 1953 by the Kingdom's Prime Minister, Prince [[Khalifa bin Salman Al Khalifa]]. ==Achievements and Honors== The club's first international achievement was in 1982 when Riffa placed second in the [[Gulf Club Champions Cup|GCC Club Cup]]. This was an important achievement for the club and Bahraini football in general as it helped the region take notice of the talent available in Bahrain. *'''[[Bahraini Premier League]]: 11''' :: 1982, 1987, 1990, 1993, 1997, 1998, 2000, 2003, 2005, 2012, 2014 *'''[[Bahraini King's Cup]]: 5''' :: 1973, 1985, 1986, 1998, 2010 *'''[[Bahraini FA Cup]]: 4''' :: 2000, 2001, 2004, 2014 *'''[[Bahraini Crown Prince Cup]]: 4''' :: 2002, 2003, 2004, 2005 ==Performance in AFC competitions== * '''[[AFC Champions League]]''': 2 appearances ::[[1988-89 Asian Club Championship|1988–89]]: Group Stage ::[[AFC Champions League 2004|2004]]: Group Stage * '''[[Asian Club Championship]]''': 5 appearances ::[[Asian Club Championship 1989|1989]]: Qualifying Stage ::[[Asian Club Championship 1992|1992]]: Qualifying – 1st round ::[[Asian Club Championship 1995|1995]]: Second Round ::[[Asian Club Championship 1997|1997]]: withdrew in First Round ::[[Asian Club Championship 1999|1999]]: First Round * '''[[AFC Cup]]''': 4 appearance ::[[AFC Cup 2010|2010]]: Semi-final ::[[AFC Cup 2014|2013]]: Round 16 ::[[AFC Cup 2014|2014]]: Round 16 ::[[AFC Cup 2015|2015]]: Group Stage ==Notable Managers== *{{flagicon|Germany}} [[Uli Maslo]] (1985–88), (1993–94) *{{flagicon|Croatia}} [[Rodion Gačanin]] (July 1, 2003 – June 30, 2005) *{{flagicon|Croatia}} [[Dragan Talajić]] (July 1, 2005 – June 30, 2006) *{{flagicon|Netherlands}} [[Eelco Schattorie]] (2006–07) *{{flagicon|Croatia}} [[Srećko Juričić]] (July 1, 2007 – Dec 31, 2007) *{{flagicon|Netherlands}} [[Wilco van Buuren]] ''(Youth Team Director)'' *{{flagicon|Brazil}} [[Julio Peixoto]] *{{flagicon|Brazil}} [[Stefano Impagliazzo]] (2011–13) *{{flagicon|Romania}} [[Florin Motroc]] (June 1, 2013 – 2014) ==External links== *[http://www.facebook.com/alriffasc Club's Official Facebook page] *[http://www.facebook.com/khaled.assuwaidi Club's Official Agent] *[http://www.alwaqt.com/art.php?aid=19375&hi=الشيخ%20إبراهيم%20بن%20خالد%20آل%20خليفة Article on Riffa Club first achievement]{{dead link|date=April 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} {{Bahraini Premier League}} [[Category:Football clubs in Bahrain]] [[Category:Association football clubs established in 1953]] [[Category:1953 establishments in Bahrain]] {{Bahrain-footyclub-stub}}

{{Use dmy dates|date=November 2012}} [[File:SteveBucknor.JPG|thumb|right|150px|[[Umpire (cricket)|Umpire]] [[Steve Bucknor]], whose decisions in the Test were controversial and led to him being dropped from officiating in the Third Test.]] [[File:Bhajji.jpg|thumb|right|150px|[[Indian cricket team|Indian]] spinner, [[Harbhajan Singh]] was charged with racial abuse.]] The '''Second Test''' in the [[Indian cricket team in Australia in 2007–08|Indian cricket team's tour of Australia for the 2007–08 summer]] was a controversial [[Test cricket]] match played over five days at the [[Sydney Cricket Ground]] from 2 to 6 January 2008. [[Australia national cricket team|Australia]] won the match by 122 runs with minutes to spare at the end of the fifth day. The match attained notoriety owing to the number of [[Umpire (cricket)|umpiring]] wrong decisions given by international umpires [[Steve Bucknor]] and [[Mark Benson]] and accusations of poor sportsmanship against both teams. The match ended in a dramatic defeat of the Indian team in the final ten minutes of the five-day match, with some commentators suggesting that the umpiring mistakes had a major impact on the course of the match.{{cite news | author = | publisher = BBC | url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/hi/cricket/7174992.stm | title=India to continue Australia tour | accessdate=8 January 2008 | date=8 January 2008}} The result ensured that Australia retained the [[Border–Gavaskar Trophy]], as well as taking [[Ricky Ponting]]'s team to 16 consecutive Test wins, equalling the previous Test record, also held by Australia under [[Steve Waugh]]. The controversy was termed by parts of the media as ''Bollyline'', a reference to the 1930s controversy [[Bodyline]].{{cite news | url = http://blogs.guardian.co.uk/sport/2008/01/08/spirit_issue_haunts_ponting_as.html | title = Spirit issue haunts Ponting as punters desert boorish Baggy Green | publisher = The Guardian | accessdate = 7 January 2008 | date = 7 January 2008 | author = Alex Brown | location=London }} The name, a [[portmanteau]] of [[Bodyline]] and [[Bollywood]], is tongue in cheek, but by referencing Bodyline, hints at the potential seriousness of the rift between the Indians and Australians.{{cite news | url = http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/sport/cricket/article3149357.ece | title = Cricket split by Bollyline tour | publisher = The Times | date = 7 January 2008 | accessdate = 7 January 2008 | author = Richard Hobson | location=London }} Indeed, according to [[Steve Waugh]], the affair "now has the potential to affect relations between the countries". The Test itself was tightly contested, setting up a fifth (final) day in which the match could have been won by either team, but was most likely to be drawn. The match featured [[century (cricket)|centuries]] by batsmen on every day of the match. Three four-wicket hauls were achieved and [[Brett Lee]] achieved a five-wicket haul in the first innings. Both [[Anil Kumble]] and [[Michael Clarke (cricketer)|Michael Clarke]] were, at individual points in the game, on a [[hat-trick]]. [[All-rounder]] [[Andrew Symonds]] was at the centre of much of the action, achieving 162[[not out|*]] and 61 with the bat and taking 3/51 in India's second innings. Symonds was awarded [[man of the match]]. Controversies abounded; as well as the multiple umpiring incidents that were placed in the spotlight by the narrowness of the victory, Indian spinner [[Harbhajan Singh]] was charged with racial abuse in an altercation with [[Andrew Symonds]]. Harbhajan was banned by the match referee [[Mike Procter]] for three Test matches although the charges were downgraded on 29 January 2008 to the lesser charge of using abusive language and the ban was lifted. The Indian team had earlier protested and threatened to pull out of the tour.{{cite press release | title=Harbhajan Singh found guilty of offence under ICC's Code of Conduct |publisher=ICC |date=7 January 2008 |url=http://icc-cricket.yahoo.com/media-release/2008/january/media-release20080107-7.html |accessdate=8 January 2008 }} The match produced bitterness on both sides and an announcement by the Indian team that they would abandon their tour, followed by dramatic intervention by the [[International Cricket Council]] (ICC). __TOC__ ==Context== {{Unreferenced section|date=January 2008}} Australia had won the first Test played the previous week at the [[Melbourne Cricket Ground]] by a margin of 337 runs, needing only four days to secure victory. Australia were seeking a 16th consecutive Test win to equal the record set by [[Steve Waugh]]'s team between late-1999 and early-2001. The first match had led to media consternation about the appropriateness of India's batting strategy. [[Rahul Dravid]] had been promoted up the batting order from number three to open along with [[Wasim Jaffer]], while regular opener [[Dinesh Karthik]] was dropped prior to the first Test. This was done to create a middle-order vacancy for [[Yuvraj Singh]], who had scored a century in India's previous Test, when he substituted for the injured [[Sachin Tendulkar]]. During the first Test, both Dravid and Jaffer failed to pass 20 in either innings, with the former attracting attention for his particularly slow and defensive approach. This allowed the Australian bowling to assert control over the Indian batsmen from the outset and prevent them from gaining the momentum at the outset. Yuvraj also failed; he was particularly fidgety in scoring 0 and 5. The failures of the rearranged line-up prompted calls for the return of [[Virender Sehwag]], who had been taken on tour as the reserve opener. Sehwag had been dropped from the side in early-2007 and had been unproductive in recent [[Ranji Trophy]] matches in India; however, his extremely aggressive approach had been successful against Australia in the past and cricket pundits felt that he could counter-attack the Australian bowlers, rather than letting their new ball attack seize the initiative. Jaffer, Dravid and Yuvraj were all mooted as possible omissions to make way for Sehwag. [[File:Master Blaster at work.jpg|thumb|250px|right|[[Sachin Tendulkar]], shown here in batting in the first Test a week prior, was expected to continue to score runs at the [[Sydney Cricket Ground]], where he had scored 241* on his last tour]] Australia fielded an unchanged XI, whereas India made one change: the injured [[Zaheer Khan]] was replaced by fellow paceman [[Ishant Sharma]], a 19-year-old playing in his third Test match. The match was preceded by speculation as to how attractive the play would be. The first Test was played on a pitch that was slow and somewhat irregular in behaviour, and the commentators were optimistic that the second Test would lead to more attractive batting, particularly from the Indians, who had amassed 7/705 and 2/211 in their previous outing in 2003–04. Tendulkar (148* in 1991–92, 241* in 2003–04) and [[V. V. S. Laxman]] (167 in 1999–2000, 178 in 2003–04) had both scored much-lauded Test centuries at the ground. ==Scorecard== {| style="background:transparent;" |style="width:8em;"| '''Match referee''' || {{flagicon|RSA}} [[Mike Procter]] |- style="vertical-align:top;" | '''Field umpires''' || {{flagicon|West Indies}} [[Steve Bucknor]]
{{flagicon|ENG}} [[Mark Benson]] |- | '''Third umpire''' || {{flagicon|AUS}} [[Bruce Oxenford]] |- | '''Toss''' || {{cr|AUS}} elected to bat first |- | '''Result''' || {{cr|AUS}} win by 122 runs |- | '''Series impact''' || {{cr|AUS}} lead 4 match series 2–0 |- | '''Man of the Match''' || {{flagicon|AUS}} [[Andrew Symonds]] |} ===Australian innings=== {| border="1" cellpadding="1" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 85%; border: gray solid 1px; border-collapse: collapse; text-align: center; width: 100%;" class=wikitable |- ! colspan="1" | {{cr|AUS}} ! colspan="2" | First Innings ! colspan="2" | Second Innings |- ! [[Batsman]] ! [[Dismissal (cricket)|Method of dismissal]] ! [[Run (cricket)|Runs]] ! [[Dismissal (cricket)|Method of dismissal]] ! [[Run (cricket)|Runs]] |- | [[Phil Jaques|P. A. Jaques]] || [[Caught (cricket)|c]] [[Mahendra Singh Dhoni|Dhoni]] [[bowling (cricket)|b]] [[R. P. Singh]] || 0 || c [[Yuvraj Singh]] b [[Anil Kumble|Kumble]] || 42 |- | [[Matthew Hayden|M. L. Hayden]] || c [[Sachin Tendulkar|Tendulkar]] b [[R. P. Singh]] || 13 || c [[Wasim Jaffer|Jaffer]] b [[Anil Kumble|Kumble]] || 123 |- | [[Captain (cricket)|*]] [[Ricky Ponting|R. T. Ponting]] || [[Leg before wicket|lbw]] b [[Harbhajan Singh]] || 55 || c [[V. V. S. Laxman|Laxman]] b [[Harbhajan Singh]] || 1 |- | [[Michael Hussey|M. E. K. Hussey]] || c [[Sachin Tendulkar|Tendulkar]] b [[R. P. Singh]] || 41 || [[not out]] || 145 |- | [[Michael Clarke (cricketer)|M. J. Clarke]] || [[Leg before wicket|lbw]] b [[Harbhajan Singh]] || 1 || c [[Rahul Dravid|Dravid]] b [[Anil Kumble|Kumble]] || 0 |- | [[Andrew Symonds|A.
